intro.title: INTRODUCTION
intro.content:
To solve many of the most pressing problems in the world, it will be necessary to help people create new positive behaviors. Whether your goal is to improve mental health, stop global warming, or mitigate risks from advanced technologies, behavior change challenges will stand in the way. Sometimes, these challenges will involve the behaviors of individuals, consumers, or aid recipients. Other times, they will involve the behaviors of politicians, government officials, or CEOs. You may also need to apply these strategies to yourself to solve problems in your own life.

Yet behavior change frequently fails. Why does it fail? And what can you do to make it more likely to succeed?

We’ve created the Ten Conditions for Change framework to help answer these questions. We hope this framework will enhance your efforts to improve the world, or to change your own life for the better.

There are, of course, a number of useful behavior change frameworks already in existence. With that fact in mind, we’ve specifically aimed to create a framework that:

  1. can easily be applied to practical problems in a step-by-step fashion by individuals and teams, regardless of their level of experience designing behavior change interventions; and that…
  2. provides a comprehensive system that can account for the huge range of different techniques used in practice (i.e., not simplifying the realm of consideration to a limited number of techniques).

At the bottom of this page, we also provide simplified summaries of a number of other behavior change frameworks, and explain how each relates to our Ten Conditions for Change model.

intro.title: OVERVIEW
intro.content:
This framework provides ten “conditions for change” that are designed to be sufficient for succeeding at creating a new positive behavior. That is, we provide ten conditions that are very likely to produce behavior change if the intended person or population meets all of them. This structure also implies that any person who is failing to carry out a desired behavior change likely isn’t meeting one or more of these ten conditions. If you can increase the likelihood of meeting these conditions, you can increase the chance that behavior change will occur. By “condition” in this context, we mean “a state of affairs that must be satisfied in order for a particular outcome to occur.” In other words, we think that behavior change is likely to occur when these ten states of affairs are satisfied.

That means that this framework provides a systematic way to analyze a desired behavior for a desired person or population, and then to develop a strategy to increase the chance of successful adoption of the behavior. It also provides a method for analyzing why the behavior is not occurring already.

This framework is specifically designed for positive, “complex” behaviors which require the target person or population to engage willingly in the change and to perform multiple actions across time.

The Ten Conditions for Change framework provides a way of organizing and systematizing thinking about behavior change. There are numerous behavior change strategies—so many that it’s hard to know where to begin. This framework can help you identify those strategies that are most appropriate for your situation and mission. Furthermore, it’s easy to miss important considerations in behavior change projects, and these overlooked considerations may ultimately lead to failure. By using this systematic process, we think you will be less likely to overlook important details regarding what you need to make your behavior change efforts succeed.

Structure

The framework is organized into three main phases: DECISION, ACTION, and CONTINUATION. The ten conditions together make up these three phases. Here again is an outline of the whole framework:

  1. DECISION
    1. Considers changing the behavior
    2. Desires changing the behavior
    3. Intends to change the behavior
  1. ACTION
    1. Remembers to perform each action
    2. Believes performing each action will help achieve the goal
    3. Chooses to perform each action
    4. Knows how to perform each action
    5. Has needed resources to perform each action
    6. Embodies skills and traits needed to perform each action
  1. CONTINUATION
    1. Maintains attributes required to perform future needed actions

The DECISION phase refers to conditions that are sufficient for a person to decide to change their behavior. For instance, if someone smokes cigarettes habitually, they’ll have to make a decision to quit before they’ll take action to quit. Often, a decision only needs to be made once; but if the target person later changes their mind about changing their behavior, then the decision will need to be re-made.

The ACTION phase refers to conditions that are sufficient for a person to perform the various actions that together constitute a successful behavior change. Most complex behaviors will involve taking a number of different actions which are spread out across time, and the ACTION phase should be applied to each of these actions separately. For instance, if someone is trying to completely quit smoking, they may have to change their behavior of buying cigarettes and their behavior of borrowing cigarettes from people at events, and perhaps also replace the habitual action of smoking with some alternative action instead.

The CONTINUATION phase refers to conditions that are sufficient for a person to continue the DECISION and ACTION processes (that is, to prevent those conditions from failing to be met after initial actions are performed and as time passes). So, for instance, if a person avoids smoking cigarettes one time but finds the experience so frustrating that it changes their opinion about quitting, or if a person’s motivation for quitting cigarettes falls over time, then the CONTINUATION phase would involve diagnosing and fixing the person’s negative attitudes or lack of motivation so that they can re-make the DECISION to quit and then re-perform the ACTIONs required to quit.

Statuses

Each of the conditions can have one of three statuses:

  • met = this condition is already met, is likely to be met, or is usually met by the target population; therefore this condition should not be a target for improvement
  • unmet = this condition is not met, is unlikely to be met, or is often not met by the target population; therefore this condition should be a target for improvement
  • unknown = it is unknown whether or not this condition is met; therefore more research is needed to understand whether this condition should be a target for improvement

As you’re thinking about trying to get someone (yourself or a target population) to adopt a new, positive behavior, consider the status of each of the ten conditions relative to that behavior. If a condition has already been met, then you will most likely not need to focus on it in your behavioral intervention. If a condition has not been met, then you’ll want to select and apply interventions to ensure that the condition gets met.

It’s also important to note that the above statuses aren’t black and white: it’s possible that a condition might be met 70% of the time, or met by just 70% of the population, or unknown among 70% of the population, etc. Thus, it may be necessary to set thresholds for the statuses to determine that a condition is met well enough that it is no longer a bottleneck for the behavior. For example, you might say to yourself, “When 70% of the population meets a condition, I’ll consider that condition to have been ‘met.’” Or, “A condition will no longer have a status of ‘unknown’ once I have information about at least 70% of the population.” It is unlikely that 100% of the population will meet a condition 100% of the time, and waiting for such an ideal state of affairs is unrealistic in many situations. The key question is: “Has this condition been met to a sufficient degree that it is no longer preventing adoption of the new, positive behavior?”

If you’re not sure whether or not a condition has been met, then it’s very important to gather more information in order to figure out whether it needs to be a focus. If you decide that you need to gather more information about a particular condition, then consider possible information gathering methods, like:

  • interviewing or surveying the target population to understand their current behaviors and the forces that drive their behaviors
  • discussing the matter with experts
  • reading academic studies and papers
  • analyzing the data you may already have collected from existing users, or analyzing data that others have collected on the target population

Select and implement whichever information gathering methods seems most likely to answer the question about how well the condition has been met.

Other Considerations

In practice, given your role, your resources, and the nature of the problem, you may only be capable of influencing some of the ten conditions in this framework and not others. Similarly, not all of the conditions are equally likely to improve. If multiple conditions for change are not met, you will likely want to focus first on the one or two that would be easiest or most cost-effective to change; but it may still be worth analyzing the other remaining conditions anyway to make sure that the conditions outside of your control don’t doom your project to failure.

If a previous behavior change project failed, going through this list of ten conditions can also help you figure out why it failed. Ask yourself: “Which of the conditions likely weren’t satisfied, therefore causing the target population to fail to adopt the target behavior?”

intro.title: HOW TO USE THIS FRAMEWORK
intro.content:
Below, we’ve laid out how to use this framework to create a new, positive behavior, whether in your own life or in the lives of a target population. These steps assume that you already have a desired behavior in mind that you know would create significant benefits (if it was adopted).

If you don’t already have a desired behavior in mind, or if you are unsure that the behavior you have in mind would create significant benefits, then we recommend instead starting by writing down an outcome or benefit that you’d like to achieve. Next, brainstorm a list of many possible behaviors that could lead to that outcome. Once you’ve come up with a list of possible behaviors, pick the behavior that you believe would yield the largest positive benefit relative to how difficult you think it would be to create that behavior. Then, carry out the following steps on the chosen behavior.

To simplify this process, we’ve created an interactive program to help you walk through these steps!

Once you’ve got the desired behavior in mind, you’re ready to begin!

Step 1: Select Behavior

Pick a concrete, positive behavior you’d like to create and a specific person or population who would ideally engage in this behavior. This behavior should be targeted at improving the world or (if the target person is you) improving your own life. Ideally, you should consider multiple options for positive behaviors, and then choose among them based on how much positive benefit you predict they would cause and how hard they would be to create.

Alternatively, you could pick a past behavior change effort that failed and perform a “postmortem” analysis to try to figure out what went wrong with it. Ask yourself, “What positive outcome do I want? And what behavior adopted by which population would potentially achieve this outcome?” or “What behavior change did I fail to achieve in the past?”

Example: If you hope to fight Hepatitis B, and parents in a given region often don’t vaccinate their children, then you might decide that the behavior you want to create is for parents to bring their children in for Hepatitis B vaccinations.

Step 2: Consider DECISION Conditions

For each of the three conditions for change in the DECISION phase, ask yourself, “To what extent is this condition met by this person?” or “What percentage of people in this population meet this condition?”

Example: If parents in your target region largely don’t know about Hepatitis B vaccines for children, then you’ll need to help them meet the “Considers” condition. If they do know about the vaccine but don’t understand the benefit of vaccination, then you’ll need to help them meet the “Desires” condition. If parents do want to vaccinate their children but don’t know when or where to get the vaccines, and hence have no plan to follow through on vaccinating their children, then you’ll need to help them meet the “Intends” condition.

Step 3: Break Behavior into ACTION Sequences

Then, break the behavior down into a series of actions that a person can perform to fully succeed at the behavior.

Note that most complex behaviors will require a number of different actions to be performed. Furthermore, there might be multiple sequences of actions that could lead a person to succeed at this behavior, so you’ll want to choose the sequence of actions that is easiest to implement and that is still sufficient for engaging in the desired behavior. Ask yourself, “Of all of the sequences of actions that could produce this behavior, which one makes the most sense in this situation? Which one is easiest to carry out?”

Example: Vaccination might be accomplished in multiple ways. In some areas, both doctors and drugstores offer vaccination. In some cases, insurance companies may have to be consulted. You may decide that, given the particulars of your target region, visiting a local doctor who will bill the vaccination to a person’s insurance company makes the most sense and is the easiest and most cost-effective course of action for most people. Also, the HepB vaccine in particular requires three separate doses at zero, one, and six to twelve months after birth. So, a prescribed sequence of actions might be: (1) Allow doctors to administer the first dose within twenty-four hours of birth in the hospital (unless the child has a low birth weight, in which case postpone all doses by a month); (2) visit your local family doctor or pediatrician for the second dose a month after the child is born; and (3) visit your local family doctor or pediatrician for the third dose six months after the child is born.

Step 4: Consider ACTION Conditions

Once you have settled on a sequence of actions that constitute the positive behavior, then you’ll want to think about those actions individually. For each distinct type of action, consider each of the six conditions for change in the ACTION phase, and ask yourself, “To what extent is this condition met by this person?” or “What percentage of people in this population meet this condition?”

Example: If parents allow the first dose to be administered in the hospital but will likely forget the second and third doses, then you’ll need to help them meet the “Remembers” condition. If parents don’t understand why three doses are necessary, then you’ll need to help them meet the “Believes” condition. If parents are inclined to put off the latter doses, then you’ll need to help them meet the “Chooses” condition. If parents don’t have health insurance and don’t know how to sign up for it, then you’ll need to help them meet the “Has” and “Knows” conditions. If the parents don’t speak the local language, then you’ll need to help them meet the “Embodies” condition. (The main type of action in the case of vaccination is visiting the doctor to receive the vaccination; if there were multiple types of actions, then you’d need to consider the above conditions for each type.)

Step 5: Consider the CONTINUATION Condition

Then, review the condition for change in the CONTINUATION phase, and ask yourself, “Is it likely that the conditions in the DECISION and ACTION phase may shift for the worse as time passes or as some of the actions are completed? If so, when, where, and how will the process break down in the future?”

Example: If any of the above conditions might become un-met as time passes, then you’ll have to find ways to help parents re-meet those conditions. For example, if children have negative reactions to the first doses of the vaccine and parents become worried about allowing their children to receive the second and third doses, then you’ll have to find ways to help them re-meet the “Desires,” “Believes,” and/or “Chooses” conditions. Or if the government decides to stop subsidizing healthcare and a significant portion of the population loses access to health insurance, then you’ll have to find ways to help them re-meet the “Has” condition.

Step 6: Choose Strategies

As you review all of the conditions mentioned, keep in mind that it often turns out that some of the conditions will already be met automatically and so require no work, whereas others will only be met if appropriate interventions are used.

The conditions for change that you think are not already well met provide hypotheses about how to increase the chance that the behavior will be changed. For each condition that is not well met, consider the provided example strategies for improving that condition, or brainstorm your own strategies. Consider which strategies seem promising regarding the intended behavior change for the intended population given each strategy’s likelihood of success and difficulty of implementation. Now, ask yourself, “Given all of the conditions for change that are not well met and all of the relevant strategies for meeting that condition, which would be the most effective for me to work on? Which do I predict will provide the biggest expected improvements in behavior change relative to their cost, effort, or difficulty of implementation?”

Example: If parents don’t know about the HepB vaccine at all, then (to help them meet the “Considers” condition) you might run an ad campaign on TV or on a major social network. If parents are likely to forget about the second and third dose appointments, then (to help them meet the “Remembers” condition) you might remind them with text message, email, and phone call reminders. If parents falsely believe that the vaccine will cause their children to develop autism, then (to help them meet the “Desires,” “Believes,” and/or “Chooses” conditions) you might develop and distribute a free pamphlet that obstetricians can give to new mothers that clearly explains the benefits of vaccinations.

preface.title: PREFACE
preface.content:
Behavior change is hard. The Ten Conditions for Change framework is designed to make it easier, whether your goal is to increase the number of life-saving vaccinations worldwide, or just to get yourself to go to the gym more often. This framework provides ten “Conditions for Change,” which are designed to be sufficient for creating a new positive behavior. Read on to learn how you can use the framework.

Successfully adopting a complex, positive behavior involves:

  1. making a DECISION to adopt the new behavior,
  2. performing a number of ACTIONs that comprise the new behavior, and
  3. ensuring the CONTINUATION of the relevant conditions for success as time passes.

For instance, if the behavior you are trying to create is going to the gym daily, then the three phases might look like this:

More specifically, a person will very likely continue to engage in a new positive behavior if the ten conditions are met.

There are three conditions to meet in the DECISION phase:

   Considers the behavior
   Desires to engage in the behavior
   Intends to engage in the behavior

There are six conditions to meet for every ACTION:

   Remembers to perform each action
   Believes attempting each action will help achieve a goal
   Chooses to perform each action over other available actions
   Knows how to perform each action
   Has needed resources and permission to perform each action
   Embodies skills and traits needed to perform each action

And there is one condition to meet for CONTINUATION:

   Maintains attributes required to perform future needed actions

Here you can see each condition in its corresponding phase:

The Ten Conditions are designed to be jointly sufficient (rather than necessary) for a behavior to occur. That means that if all of the Ten Conditions are met, then a person will very likely engage in the desired behavior:

This also means that if a behavior is not occurring, then it is very likely that one or more of the Ten Conditions is not being met. Thus you can use the Ten Conditions as a diagnostic tool to pinpoint why a behavior is not occurring. Just go condition-by-condition to find the conditions that are failing:

Read on to learn much more about how to use the framework, explore how each of the Ten Conditions works, and discover hundreds of behavior change strategies organized by which of the Ten Conditions they target.

biases.name: Appeal to Authority Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Authority Fallacy is the argument that a statement is correct because it was made by a person or source that the audience regards as authoritative.
biases.examples: For example: "As Samuel Johnson said, 'patriotism is the last refuge of the scoundrel.'"
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, it could help to analyze the message itself after disconnecting it from the messenger. For example, "I know you've adopted Diet X because Dr. Oz recommended it, but is it really true that X is safe and effective? I think you should see what the research shows about X before adopting it."

To leverage this fallacy, you could ask trusted authority figures to deliver messages. For example, "I'm Alex Trebec, and I want you to know how important it is to buy life insurance." biases.name: Hostile Media Effect (Disconfirmation Bias)
biases.description: The Hostile Media Effect refers to a form of Disconfirmation Bias, whereby people who hold more polarized political views are more likely to see a media report as being politically biased.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In the first major study of this phenomenon, pro-Palestinian students and pro-Israeli students were shown the same news filmstrips pertaining to the then-recent (1982) Sabra and Shatila massacre of Palestinian refugees by Christian Lebanese militia fighters in Beirut during the Lebanese Civil War. On a number of objective measures, both sides found that these identical news clips were slanted in favor of the other side. This effect is interesting to psychologists because it appears to be a reversal of the otherwise pervasive effects of confirmation bias. In other words, in this area, people seem to pay more attention to information that contradicts rather than supports their existing views.

biases.name: Mere Exposure Effect
biases.description: The Mere Exposure Effect refers to a tendency to express undue liking for things merely because of familiarity with them.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Charles Goetzinger conducted an experiment using the Mere Exposure Effect on his class at Oregon State University. Goetzinger had a student come to class wearing a large black bag with only his feet visible. That student (student A) sat on a table in the back of the classroom. Goetzinger's experiment was to observe if the students would treat Student A in accordance with the Mere Exposure Effect. His hypothesis was confirmed. The students in the class first treated Student A with hostility, which over time turned into curiosity, and eventually friendship. This experiment confirms (Zajonc's) Mere Exposure Effect: by simply presenting the student wearing the black bag over and over again to the other students, their attitudes were changed.

biases.name: System Justification
biases.description: System Justification Theory refers to a social psychology theory that posits that people are motivated to desire, maintain, and defend the status quo. This bias is motivational in nature (which makes it conceptually distinct from the (cognitive) phenomenon of Status Quo Bias). System Justification appears to be exacerbated under conditions of psychological threat, or when someone's needs are being met by the system that they are justifying.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Early SJT (Situational Judgement Tests) research focused on compensatory stereotypes. Experiments suggested that the widespread endorsement of stereotypes such as "poor but happy" or "rich but miserable" exist to balance out the gap between those of low and high socioeconomic status. Later work suggested that these compensatory stereotypes are preferred by leftists while rightists prefer non-complimentary stereotypes such as "poor and dishonest" or "rich and honest", which rationalize inequality rather than compensate for it.

biases.name: Typical Mind Fallacy
biases.description: The Typical Mind Fallacy is the fallacious assumption that one's own mind is "typical" and that other minds in the general population are therefore similar to one's own.
biases.experimentalEvidence: There was a debate, in the late 1800s, about whether "imagination" was simply a turn of phrase or a real phenomenon. That is, can people actually create images in their minds which they see vividly, or do they simply say "I saw it in my mind" as a metaphor for considering what it looked like? The debate was resolved by Francis Galton, who gave people some very detailed surveys, and found that some people did have mental imagery, while others did not. The ones who did simply assumed everyone did, and the ones who didn't simply assumed everyone didn't, to the point of coming up with absurd justifications for why they were lying or misunderstanding the question. There was a wide spectrum of imaging ability, from about five percent of people with perfect eidetic imagery to three percent of people completely unable to form mental images.

substeps.title: 2. Desires to engage in the behavior
substeps.description:
Even if we've considered adopting a new behavior, we're very unlikely to actually do so unless we desire to adopt it. There are two different types of desire:
  1. Intuitive Desire—a gut level positive feeling or emotion about engaging in a behavior (e.g., "I have a good feeling about doing this behavior")
  2. Reflective Desire—an analytical, reasoned belief that the behavior is worthwhile (e.g., "I've carefully considered the pros and cons and concluded that the benefits of the behavior outweigh the costs").
To make a behavior likely, it's critical to have at least one of these two forms of desires, but it's best if the person desires the behavior in both the intuitive and reflective senses.
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...the advertisement she saw hadn't mentioned the potentially life-changing benefits of therapy for anxiety.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...a friend hadn't described to him the suffering of animals and the environmental damage caused by factory farming.

interventions.DESCRIPTION / IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY:: People tend to ignore opportunity costs when considering how good an action is (i.e. they don't necessarily take into account what they would have done with that time and money had they not taken the action). Therefore, when a person has an undesired behavior, help them to understand the opportunity cost of doing it - what they're giving up by doing it that they may not have considered - to motivate the new behavior that doesn't have that opportunity cost. For instance, if the new behavior is to spend more time with their kids, but currently they are spending hours watching TV every day, the opportunity cost of watching TV could be clearly explained.

interventions.DESCRIPTION / IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY::
Step 1: Rate on a Likert scale your current perspective on this issue.
Step 2: Ask to explain in detail why this is the right number for them right now.
Step 3: Ask them to try to recall the first time they remember ever hearing about or encountering this issue (to get them to realize that they probably didn’t develop the opinion in a very informed or independent way).
Step 4: Ask them to recall and tell you about in detail experiences that have had with this issue since then. You can share your experiences too at this stage. It should NOT feel like an argument or debate at all, just two people sharing their personal experiences.
Step 5: Ask them to rate their feelings about the issue again on the original scale. 
This technique has been proven effective in changing people's minds on LGBT rights (12% of the people did).

biases.name: Ad Hoc Rescue
biases.description: An Ad Hoc Rescue is an attempt to save a cherished belief by repeatedly revising the argument in favor of it to explain away problems.
biases.examples: For example: "I don't care if it gives me better cardiovascular health, better mental health, better sleep quality, and longer life expectancy---I still think that regular exercise would just be torture."

Of course, this assumes that they share the same values as you but believe other strategies are more effective. biases.name: Ad Hominem Fallacy
biases.description: The Ad Hominem Fallacy occurs when a person attacks the arguer instead of the argument in order to conclude that the argument is false.
biases.examples: For example: "That researcher is overweight! We can't trust their meta-analysis about the health impacts of saturated fat intake."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this bias, you could ask people to replace the actual messenger with a trusted imaginary messenger (or merely omit the messenger altogether); then, ask them to reconsider the message.

To leverage this bias, you could deliver the message using a messenger that you know the audience will trust. In such a case, it's still important to tell the audience that the claims are true for reasons other than that they're being delivered by a trusted messenger; the trusted messenger only acts as a sort of Trojan horse to deploy the message behind the defenses of the audience, not as proof of the message's veracity.

biases.name: Affirmative Conclusion from a Negative Premise Fallacy
biases.description: The Affirmative Conclusion from a Negative Premise Fallacy occurs when an affirmative conclusion is assumed to follow from two negative premises; for example: "A is not a subset of B. B is not a subset of C. Therefore, A is a subset of C."
biases.examples:
For example: "We don't read that trash. People who read that trash don't appreciate real literature. Therefore, we appreciate real literature." 

Another example: "People who take smoke breaks at work aren't the type who can never relax. People who can't relax don't have a healthy work-life balance. So, people who take smoke breaks have a healthy work-life balance."
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, draw Venn diagrams to illustrate the relationships of the categories involved to correct the logic of the faulty argument. (This is a useful strategy for many errors that occur when reasoning about categories.) Also, give empirical evidence that contradicts the faulty conclusion in order to update the person's beliefs (in case their reasoning is motivated by other factors).
biases.content:

Another example: “People who take smoke breaks at work aren’t the type who can never relax. People who can’t relax don’t have a healthy work-life balance. So, people who take smoke breaks have a healthy work-life balance.”

To overcome this fallacy, draw Venn diagrams to illustrate the relationships of the categories involved to correct the logic of the faulty argument. (This is a useful strategy for many errors that occur when reasoning about categories.) Also, give empirical evidence that contradicts the faulty conclusion in order to update the person’s beliefs (in case their reasoning is motivated by other factors).

biases.name: Affirming a Disjunct Fallacy
biases.description: Affirming a Disjunct Fallacy is a logical fallacy made in deductive arguments in which it is falsely assumed that if one statement or category applies, then another cannot apply. This fallacy has the form: "A or B. A. Therefore, not B." If it is possible for both A and B to be true at the same time (i.e., if they're not mutually exclusive), then it is erroneous to conclude that one disjunct must be false merely because the other disjunct is true.
biases.examples:
For example, someone might believe that either "you stop smoking socially at parties" *or* "you keep enjoying parties" without realizing that the two are not mutually exclusive categories. (In other words, they may not realize that it is possible to stop smoking socially at parties while still enjoying them.)

For example: "You can love America, or you can be a socialist."
biases.manualKeywords: disjunct, affirm, either, or, inclusive, exclusive
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, ask: "Is it possible for both disjuncts to be true at the same time?" For example: "Can a person quit drinking and still have fun?" Also, show examples where both disjuncts are true at the same time. In particular, it's important to show anecdotal evidence from the lives of loved ones when a person's reasoning is strongly motivated by emotion and/or identity, as in the cases of religion and politics. In other words, it's important not only to ask the question "Can a person hold belief X and still be a good person?" but also to show examples of real people, especially loved ones, who *do* hold belief X and who *are* still good people.

biases.name: Anchoring Bias
biases.description: The Anchoring Bias occurs when a person's expectation about one thing is affected by something they saw, heard, or thought before. In other words, it occurs when a person relies too heavily on a specific piece of information to govern their thought process.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In one study, an audience was asked to write the last two digits of their social security number and consider whether they would pay this number of dollars for items such as wine, chocolate, and computer equipment, the values of which they did not know. They were then asked to bid for these items. The result was that the audience members with higher two-digit numbers would submit bids that were between 60% and 120% higher than those with the lower social security numbers. Put simply, the higher the (social security) number in mind, the higher the bid. The social security numbers had become their "anchors."

Currently, the cell's content is taken.com/forgetting/: Partly from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anchoring_(cognitive_bias) but looks like it is already reworded somewhat

biases.examples:
For example, when buying an expensive piece of software, the initial quote you get might anchor you to a particular price.

As another example, when negotiating a contract, the initial terms of the agreement might act as an anchor for the remainder of the negotiations. Wins might then be measured with respect to the original terms rather than in terms of absolute benefits or losses.
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this bias, define one's expectations _before_ being exposed to potential anchors (e.g., prior to obtaining quotes, entering negotiations, and so on). It might also help to be reminded that one's memory of past experiences may be out-of-date or based on incorrect information. 

To leverage this bias, one could suggest a specific number (e.g., dollar amount) as a starting point for giving, negotiating, etc.
biases.ideasForTesting: On some tests, have a question that involves someone paying $15 for a hamburger and omit that question on other tests. On all tests, have a question asking how much money one considers to be "expensive" for a hamburger. See if the $15 mark has an anchoring effect.
biases.evenMoreNotes: Idea for a within-subjects test: Ask 2 different gambling questions, one with an anchor and one without, where the test taker has to say how much he/she'd risk in a certain game for a certain probability of reward. Also must be careful that a subject's different answers don't result from the framing bias, rather than the anchoring bias.

biases.name: Anecdotal Evidence Fallacy
biases.description: The Anecdotal Evidence Fallacy is the discounting of evidence arrived at by systematic search or testing in favor of a few firsthand stories.
biases.examples: For example: "I'm going to carry on smoking. My grandfather smoked 40 cigarettes a day until he died at age 90."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, point out that anecdotes can never be generalized to a population. A population represents many individuals, but a single individual does not necessarily represent the population. So it's possible to tell a true anecdote that's nevertheless statistically rare for a population.

To leverage this fallacy, use anecdotes to describe what individual experiences may look like. If you do this, be sure to mention that the anecdotes are only part of the statistical story. In other words, remind people that "your mileage may vary."

biases.name: Appeal to Common Practice Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Common Practice Fallacy is the claim that something is true or acceptable because it's commonly practiced.
biases.examples:
For example: "This bank has some problems with corruption. But there's nothing going on here that doesn't go on in all the other banks."

Another example: "This procedure is practiced at 90% of hospitals, so it's the best option we've got for our patient!"
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, it could help to show counterexamples of times when a common practice or belief was later shown to be false, dangerous, or immoral. (This by itself doesn't prove that a claim is false; it only demonstrates that the majority isn't always right and that common practice isn't proof of truth or moral acceptability.) For example, owning slaves used to be a common practice around the world. The ubiquity of slavery, however, should not be taken as evidence that it was morally justifiable.

biases.name: Appeal to Consequences Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Consequences Fallacy is an argument in which the validity of its premise (typically a belief) is judged based on whether the consequences of that premise lead to desirable or undesirable consequences. It typically has a form like: "If P, then bad consequences. Therefore, not P." Or: "If P, then good consequences. Therefore, P!"
biases.examples:
For example: "Your theory cannot possibly be true because if it were, our lives would be meaningless."

Another example: "This new exercise plan is going to hurt like heck, so it's probably not good for me."

Another example: "The last time I tried to stop smoking, I had horrible withdrawal symptoms. So it's probably best for me to just keep smoking."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, provide absurd, extreme, or humorous counterexamples to show that the truth of a proposition is not connected to its consequences. For example: "If there were serial killers, then lots of people would die horrible deaths! Therefore, serial killers must not exist." Or: "If everyone was perfectly kind to each other, then we'd have no more wars. Therefore, everyone must already be perfectly kind to each other!"

Directly pointing out this fallacy might have the potential to backfire. This kind of reasoning can be associated with cognitive dissonance and motivated reasoning, which may decrease the degree to which people can engage rationally and productively with information or arguments contradicting their current thinking (e.g. [Rothgerber, 2020](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0195666319306324?casa_token=TbOa-8zyVboAAAAA:pwCeOrthXBA3hSOV8dSmUNyL5cIT4oeSJV3jYRNd5wCSseAtLw4rvD0cYYRU6VZRhBohasvyO7Y)). 

Motivated reasoning may become particularly problematic when the topic at hand is framed in moral terms (since topics framed in terms of morality can be associated with more polarization than those perceived through a pragmatic lens; [Abeywickrama et al., 2020](https://jspp.psychopen.eu/index.php/jspp/article/view/5263)). 

With these caveats in mind, given the right circumstances and the right person, it might sometimes be worth telling someone when it seems like this fallacy is affecting their reasoning (if the backfire risk appears to be sufficiently low). 

This may be worth taking into consideration when raising initial awareness of a given behavior or its consequences: if the target audience has certain ideas that they hold strongly and value highly, then it could backfire to convey information that directly challenges those beliefs. And when information _is_ presented that _could_ contradict someone's cherished beliefs, it might be preferable to share the information on its own---without sharing the conclusions or providing behavioral prescriptions---in order to encourage the person to come to their _own_ conclusions (for more information on this point, see the Generation Effect). 

Over the longer-term, it may help to encourage people to foster more epistemic humility, potentially through practicing dialogic argumentation in a wide variety of contexts ([Kuhn & Crowell, 2011](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0956797611402512?casa_token=j8n-fvNZXIcAAAAA%3ARQxwCnHBeC4V_rEOge0_-zqCBENDDml05g1n502cs7OTa8ADJ2pONhY88bhP2p3CHRm0C7RA6-lsww)). More research in this area is needed, but some evidence suggests that such approaches may enable people to become less attached to their desired conclusions ([Švaříček, 2019](https://www.phil.muni.cz/journals/index.php/studia-paedagogica/article/view/2063), which may increase their ability to form more realistic beliefs through the use of reasoning and evidence.

biases.name: Appeal to Fear Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Fear Fallacy is the argument that one of two things must be true and that, because one of the things is frightening, the other must be true. It usually has the form: "Either P or Q is true. Q is frightening. Therefore, P."
biases.examples: For example, someone might be experiencing symptoms consistent with a diagnosis of Panic Disorder. They might believe: "Either these symptoms represent panic attacks, or I'm just experiencing normal sensations that everyone feels. But having a Panic Disorder diagnosis sounds frightening to me. Therefore, I'm just experiencing normal sensations that everyone feels."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To leverage this fallacy, highlight undesirable or risky outcomes that would result from failure to engage in a desired behavior change. It could also help to motivate people to maintain the behavior in cases where they either fear failure itself or fear the consequences of that failure. 

To overcome this fallacy, consider how severe the person's fear is and how strongly they hold their current beliefs relating to the feared outcome(s). Then, if it seems safe to do so, it might help to encourage the person to acknowledge the fear, analyze the reasons behind it, evaluate whether the fear is justified, and manage it directly. On the other hand, if the person has strongly-held beliefs relating to the fear or its consequences, it may be preferable to seek professional support. In the meantime, the strategies for the Appeal to Consequences Fallacy may also be worth considering.

biases.name: Appeal to Flattery Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Flattery Fallacy is the use of an irrelevant compliment to slip in an unfounded claim; the audience might then accept the statement along with the flattery. It usually has the form: "You have desirable property X, so of course you'll know that P is true."
biases.examples: For example: "Intelligent and sophisticated readers will of course recognize a fallacy like this when they read one."
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, recognize it and/or point it out. It may also help to re-evaluate any claims based on the evidence supporting them, rather than other factors (such as accompanying flattery). Those trying to support others in their behavior change efforts should also avoid giving unwarranted or falsely-inflated flattery. (As well as being dishonest / unethical, this would also run the risk of backfiring via the Argument from Fallacy.)

biases.name: Appeal to Hypocrisy Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Hypocrisy Fallacy is the argument that a position is wrong because the person arguing for it does not live in accordance with it.
biases.examples:
For example: "He says lying is wrong. But look at him! He's been known to lie himself!"

Another example: "The big oil companies tell us that we as individuals should do more to prevent climate change by reducing, reusing, and recycling. But they're contributing to climate change on a massive scale, so we can't trust anything they say! So it's probably a waste of time and energy for us to reduce, reuse, and recycle."
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, you should ideally adopt the behavior in question (or give a costly signal that you intend to adopt it) before encouraging others to do so. In cases where other people are providing behavioral advice or tips, it may be advisable for the person explaining it to be selected based on their own experience in engaging in the behavior in question so that their advice is (at least perceived to be) more credible.

biases.name: Appeal to Incredulity Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Incredulity Fallacy is the dismissal of a proposition as false because it sounds unbelievable.
biases.examples:
For example, someone might think it is unbelievable that there is a free activity that can increase their lifespan, improve their physical and mental health, and improve their cognitive abilities. (But getting enough sleep each night is a free activity that does all of these things.)

Another example: "You're telling me that humans and chimpanzees shared a common ancestor? That's absurd! Humans are completely different from chimps!"
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, share any available evidence so that people can draw their own conclusions regarding the claim(s) they are doubting. It may also help to show them that a person they respect believes the claim(s).

biases.name: Appeal to Money Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Money Fallacy can occur with respect either to people or to things. When it concerns people, the fallacy is the belief that the more money a person has, the wiser or more knowledgeable they are. When it concerns things, the fallacy is the belief that the more something costs, the more valuable it must be.
biases.examples:
For example: "This product costs more, so it must be better."

Another example: "He's the richest man in the world! He must be doing something right!"
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, try challenging it directly by asking questions. For example: "Is it really true that this product is better than its competitors simply because it's the most expensive?"

To leverage this fallacy, place a relatively high price on the relevant training, equipment, or other materials required to engage in the behavior.

biases.name: Appeal to Motive Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Motive Fallacy is the claim an argument must be false because the person making it has biased or ulterior motives.
biases.examples: For example: "We can't trust the evidence that he produces because he'll sell millions of copies of his book if people believe that his theories are true."
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, avoid allowing people with relevant conflicts of interest to be the ones promoting behavior change. For example, if someone owns a high-protein product company, they should not be the person chosen to run a nutrition workshop.

biases.name: Appeal to Nature Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Nature Fallacy is the claim that natural things are automatically good and that synthetic things are automatically bad.
biases.examples:
For example: "Vaccines are unnatural. Therefore, they are bad for me."

Another example: "Why would people make genetically-modified foods? Natural foods are already perfect!"
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, provide counterexamples. If a beneficial behavior is seen as unnatural, provide evidence that it results in positive outcomes. If a detrimental behavior is seen as natural, provide evidence that it results in negative outcomes.

In some cases, this fallacy may be deeply connected to a person's worldview. If a person views humans as being a fundamentally different kind of thing than animals, then man-made things will take on a particularly significant quality that they would otherwise not have if the person were to view humans as merely being another kind of animal. For example, are skyscrapers "natural"? If one views humans as just another kind of animal, then comparing skyscrapers to anthills might seem appropriate; but to a person who views humans as being metaphysically different than animals, such a comparison might seem degrading to humans or even simply absurd. In other words, if a person is a materialist who believes that nature is just "everything that is," then skyscrapers and vaccines and sodas are just as "natural" as anthills and venom and honey. But a person who believes that humans are separate from nature will probably view man-made things with some amount of mistrust. And, of course, challenging a person's worldview is extremely difficult and likely to backfire. Offering counterexamples may still be the best course of action, but be aware that they may not be received warmly.

This fallacy may also represent a response to the facts that (1) we don't always test our inventions sufficiently well and (2) we are often motivated by profit to invent quickly. We've noticed that we have, in the past, rushed to invent products that later caused lots of damage, and that's made us skeptical about the benefits of new inventions. The concern that inventions be well-tested is valid and extremely important, but it's also separate from whether or not human inventions are "natural."

biases.name: Appeal to Novelty Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Novelty Fallacy is the belief that something is automatically better because it is new or newer.
biases.examples: For example: "The latest version of this operating system is going to make my computer faster and better."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, it could help to point out that there are significant (but often less noticeable) risks and costs associated with always having/using the newest thing. For example, adopting the latest fad diet may put one's health at risk (since there may be little research into the long-term effects of the diet). It might also help to point out that old things may more reliable, well-tested, and cheaper.

To leverage this fallacy, one could show that the target behavior can be adopted in a new way. For example, to convince people to stop smoking cigarettes (which is not a new idea), one could show them new techniques and tools for quitting, such as a new medication or a new kind of chewing gum.

biases.name: Appeal to Popular Belief Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Popular Belief Fallacy is the claim that something is true because the majority of people believe it.
biases.examples: For example: "Everyone knows that milk is essential for healthier bones."
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, point out evidence and counterexamples to demonstrate that the claim in question isn't true.

For example: “Everyone knows that milk is essential for healthier bones.”

To overcome this fallacy, point out evidence and counterexamples to demonstrate that the claim in question isn’t true.

biases.name: Appeal to Probability Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Probability Fallacy is the assumption that because something *could* happen, then it *will* happen.
biases.examples:
For example: "There are many hackers that spread worms through the internet. Therefore, if you use the internet without a firewall, it is inevitable that you will be hacked sooner or later."

Another example: "A few people have had adverse reactions to the vaccine, so I don't want to get vaccinated because I just know I'll have an adverse reaction too!"
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, describe concrete examples with similar probabilities. For example, "I know you're afraid of the negative side effects of starting your new habit, but they're about as likely as being attacked by a giant squid." Sometimes, exaggerating the person's own inference (from some probability to 100% probability) in a friendly way with humor and mild sarcasm can show them how absurd the inference is. For example, "Oh, you're afraid of having a heart attack when you exercise? You're right; that's a valid fear. Most 25-year-olds I've known have died of heart attacks while exercising, which is why there's so few of them left. It's also why doctors recommend never exercising if you're over 10 years old." Or: "All startups succeed! None have ever failed. Yours is totally going to succeed too!"

Encourage the person to seek professional help if the faulty reasoning is overlapping with [all-or-nothing thinking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_distortion#All-or-nothing_thinking) and/or with [catastrophizing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exaggeration#Cognitive_distortions), and use similar strategies to address it. To overcome this fallacy over the longer-term, it might also be beneficial to encourage the person to practice thinking more probabilistically to reduce their tendency to engage in this fallacy in the first place.

biases.name: Appeal to Ridicule Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Ridicule Fallacy is casting an opponent's argument in a light that makes it sound silly or ridiculous in order to bolster a claim that it is false.
biases.examples: For example: "If Einstein's theory of relativity is right, that would mean that when I drive my car, it gets shorter and more massive the faster I go. That's crazy!"
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, ask the person to consider whether they'd come to the same conclusion given the same evidence. It might also be possible to reduce the probability of this fallacy arising if the people and organizations presenting information about a given behavior are respected, credible, or otherwise less susceptible to ridicule.

biases.name: Appeal to Spite Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Spite Fallacy is the dismissal of a claim by appealing to a personal bias against the claimant.
biases.examples: For example: "Don't you just hate how those rich Liberal Hollywood actors go on TV to promote their agendas?"
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, it might help to point it out and encourage the person to focus on the information itself rather than the people or organization(s) conveying it. Ask someone the audience trusts to argue the case for the behavior change.

biases.name: Appeal to Tradition Fallacy
biases.description: The Appeal to Tradition Fallacy is the claim that something is true because it has (apparently) always been that way. (See also: Status Quo Bias.)
biases.examples: For example: "Marriage is the union between man and women. It has always been that way, and always should be that way. Therefore gay marriage is wrong."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome or avoid this fallacy, introduce behavior change interventions with small and incremental steps to reduce the resistance associated with breaking from tradition. Show examples, especially of a person's loved ones, who have changed their behavior and who are still "good" people, even though they've apparently abandoned tradition.

To leverage this fallacy, point out cases where someone is already engaging in a behavior long enough for them to perceive it as a tradition (in which case the Appeal to Tradition Fallacy may help them to stick to it). Also, point out ways in which the new, positive behavior aligns with a person's traditions and values.

biases.name: Appeal to Wishful Thinking
biases.description: The Appeal to Wishful Thinking Fallacy is the belief that a claim is true or false just because they strongly hope it is.
biases.examples:
For example: "The President wouldn't lie. He's our leader and a good American."

As another example, someone may desire (and thus believe) that there will be no expected negative health impacts from smoking.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome Wishful Thinking that relates to strongly-held beliefs, it might help to use similar strategies as those suggested for the Appeal to Consequences Fallacy. For hopes which are less strongly held, or in situations where the backfire risk is deemed to be sufficiently low, it may help to point out when Wishful Thinking is occurring or to provide evidence to enable the person to draw their own conclusions.

biases.name: Argument from Fallacy
biases.description: The Argument from Fallacy Fallacy (sometimes just called the "Fallacy Fallacy") is the argument that, because an embedded argument contains a flaw, its conclusion must be false. It usually has the following form (where P is an embedded argument): "If P is sound or strong, then P's conclusion is true. P is unsound or not strong. Therefore, P's conclusion is false."
biases.examples:
For example: "My opponent has just argued that the earth is round because he desperately hopes it is. He is engaging in wishful thinking (i.e., assuming that a claim is true because one wants it to be true), so his conclusion that the earth is round must be false."

Another example: "Our opponents have falsely argued that abortion should be legal because it reduces crime rates. Now that this claim has been proven false, we can conclude that abortion should be made illegal."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome the Argument from Fallacy, encourage the person to "steelman" the argument (i.e., to build the strongest possible version of their opponent's argument and then see if they can defeat it) or to focus on the information itself rather than on the fallacious ways in which it is currently being conveyed. 

It might also be possible to reduce the probability of this fallacy arising in the first place if care is taken not to promote a positive behavior (or discourage a negative one) in a way that employs fallacies.

biases.title: Argument from Fallacy

biases.name: Argument from Ignorance Fallacy
biases.description: The Argument from Ignorance Fallacy is the assertion that a proposition is necessarily true because it has not been proven false (or vice versa).
biases.examples:
For example: "We know that quantum mechanics is a true theory because every attempt to test it has failed to find evidence against the theory."

Another example: "You can't prove that unicorns *don't* exist; therefore, they *do* exist!"
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, draw on concrete examples of statements that the person already believes could be false despite the fact that the belief has not been explicitly proven false. (For example, it could be pointed out that it is still reasonable not to believe in ghosts despite not having evidence disproving their existence.)
biases.content:
The Argument from Ignorance Fallacy is the assertion that a proposition is necessarily true because it has not been proven false (or vice versa).

For example: “We know that quantum mechanics is a true theory because every attempt to test it has failed to find evidence against the theory.”

Another example: “You can’t prove that unicorns don’t exist; therefore, they do exist!”

To overcome this fallacy, draw on concrete examples of statements that the person already believes could be false despite the fact that the belief has not been explicitly proven false. (For example, it could be pointed out that it is still reasonable not to believe in ghosts despite not having evidence disproving their existence.)
biases.title: Argument from Ignorance Fallacy

biases.name: Availability Cascade
biases.description: Availability Cascade refers to a self-reinforcing cycle in which simple and apparently insightful ideas automatically spread faster than complex, obscure ideas, even if they oversimplify to the point of inaccuracy.
biases.examples:
For example, a politician may win an election because their ideas are pithier and more easily communicated. 

As another example, all other things being equal, "Jones is a transphobe" will probably spread faster than "Jones supports people's right to redefine their gender identity and pronouns but also thinks that some cases of gender dysphoria might be accompanied by depression, which should be treated first prior to the gender dysphoria being addressed," even if the latter is the correct and nuanced summary of Jones' actual views.
biases.benevolentHelper:
To combat this effect, it might help to show how an idea oversimplifies a complex phenomenon. 

To leverage the Availability Cascade, it might help to simplify (without oversimplifying) your idea and to find catchy ways to express it.

biases.name: Availability Heuristic
biases.description: The Availability Heuristic refers to a phenomenon wherein someone's prediction about an event's frequency is unduly influenced by how easily they can bring examples of that event to mind.
biases.examples: For example, people may rate the chance of death by homicide to be higher than the possibility of death due to stomach cancer, partly because the former tends to be more "newsworthy."
biases.benevolentHelper: To leverage this phenomenon, modify the physical and social environment to make the desired behavior---and its positive consequences---more salient and memorable.
biases.content:
The Availability Heuristic refers to a phenomenon wherein someone’s prediction about an event’s frequency is unduly influenced by how easily they can bring examples of that event to mind.

For example, people may rate the chance of death by homicide to be higher than the possibility of death due to stomach cancer, partly because the former tends to be more “newsworthy.”

To leverage this phenomenon, modify the physical and social environment to make the desired behavior—and its positive consequences—more salient and memorable.
biases.title: Availability Heuristic

biases.name: Backtracking Effect
biases.description: The Backtracking Effect refers to the fact that people don't like undoing or re-doing what they've already done, even when they recognize that they've made a mistake. All else being equal, when people realize they've made a mistake, they prefer to perform new work rather than to expend the same amount of effort undoing or re-doing previous work.
biases.examples: For example, suppose someone is working on a project, and a file gets deleted accidentally. The worker may find that they are much more resistant to re-doing the lost project than if that part of the project had just taken twice as long.
biases.benevolentHelper: To leverage this fallacy, especially if someone has reached the Maintains condition, it may help to point out to the person how far they have come; this might motivate them not to go backward on their behavioral goals. For example, "You've already finished seven weeks of your 5k training program! If you give up or take a break now, you'll have to redo some or all of those weeks! You don't want to have to do that, do you?"
biases.content:
The Backtracking Effect refers to the fact that people don’t like undoing or re-doing what they’ve already done, even when they recognize that they’ve made a mistake. All else being equal, when people realize they’ve made a mistake, they prefer to perform new work rather than to expend the same amount of effort undoing or re-doing previous work.

For example, suppose someone is working on a project, and a file gets deleted accidentally. The worker may find that they are much more resistant to re-doing the lost project than if that part of the project had just taken twice as long.

To leverage this fallacy, especially if someone has reached the Maintains condition, it may help to point out to the person how far they have come; this might motivate them not to go backward on their behavioral goals. For example, “You’ve already finished seven weeks of your 5k training program! If you give up or take a break now, you’ll have to redo some or all of those weeks! You don’t want to have to do that, do you?”

biases.name: Bandwagon Effect
biases.description: The Bandwagon Effect refers to a phenomenon whereby people tend to do or believe things because many other people do or believe the same. It is a phenomenon observed primarily within the fields of microeconomics, political science, and behaviorism.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In Solomon Asch's Conformity Experiments, students who participated in "vision tests" were more likely to answer questions about the length of a line incorrectly if others in the same room (in this case, confederates of Asch) who answered the question first provided incorrect answers. Similarly, if at least one of the confederates gave the correct answer, the students became far more likely to also give the correct answer.
biases.examples: For example, someone may stretch before athletic activity because they've seen a lot of other people do so, without knowing if there is evidence to support the utility of this activity.
biases.benevolentHelper:
To leverage this effect, one could draw attention to the popularity of a given desired behavior, since people might be more likely to desire it if "everyone else" seems to be adopting it. This may be useful to keep in mind when designing behavior change interventions.

To overcome this effect (especially if the behavior one is trying to adopt is not popular yet), extra effort may be required to emphasize other positive aspects of the behavior. Appeal to a person's desire to be a trendsetter or their desire to go "against the grain" of what everyone else is doing. Provide evidence to show that the popular way of doing things has negative outcomes in the long-term or at a large scale.
biases.otherNotes: The Asch Experiments demonstrate a particularly strong version of the Bandwagon Effect by showing that a person may believe something that he has direct evidence against, just because many other people believe that thing.

biases.name: Begging the Question Fallacy
biases.description: Begging the Question occurs when a proposition to be proven is assumed implicitly or explicitly in the premises of the argument. (The fallacy can also occur if the assumed premise is actually stronger or more controversial than the proposition that's being debated.)
biases.examples:
For example: "Caffeine makes people more alert because it's a stimulant."

Another example: "Killing innocent people is always wrong. The death penalty will inevitably lead to innocent people dying, so the death penalty is wrong."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To try to overcome this fallacy, it could help to point out when it occurs. One could also encourage the person to decide what they would believe if they started without their inaccurate or unnecessarily strong premise. Otherwise, this could affect the accuracy of any of a person's beliefs. (A flawed premise could lead to someone having beliefs that discourage them from desiring, planning for, or engaging in a given positive behavior.) 

It may also be useful to point out when an argument containing this fallacy fails to explain a causal mechanism. In the example above about caffeine ("Caffeine makes people more alert because it's a stimulant."), no causal mechanism has been described; the claim essentially boils down to: "Caffeine stimulates because it's a stimulant." That's true but not useful. It would be better to say something like: "Caffeine makes people more alert because it antagonizes adenosine receptors in the brain, preventing the binding of adenosine to the receptors and thus preventing the drowsy feeling induced by adenosine."

biases.name: Biased Generalizing
biases.description: Biased Generalizing refers to the act of generalizing from an unrepresentative sample (usually in such a way as to increase the strength of one's biased point of view).
biases.examples: For example, someone might say, "Both of the friends who smoke with me at parties are healthy, and so am I. Now that I think about it, all social smokers are healthy."
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this phenomenon, it might help to point out how the original data/sample/study is not necessarily generalizable to different contexts or how it's possible that a particular sample is not representative. For example, if someone has just failed in an attempt at a new behavior, it could be helpful to point out that there isn't enough information yet to assume that future attempts will be unsuccessful just because this attempt has been.

For example, if someone has just failed in an attempt at a new behavior, it could be helpful to point out that there isn’t enough information yet to assume that future attempts will be unsuccessful just because this attempt has been.

biases.name: Burden of Proof Fallacy
biases.description: The Burden of Proof Fallacy refers to the assumption that one's own argument is true unless explicitly disproven and that the onus is on those who hold alternative viewpoints to disprove that view.
biases.examples: For example, someone might say, "I maintain that long-term solar cycles are the cause of global warming. Show me I'm wrong."
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, it might help to respectfully point out to them when you notice them employing it. Over the longer-term, it might help if people practice epistemic humility and probabilistic thinking. If someone is willing to admit their beliefs could be wrong, and if they have an understanding of the concepts of probability and uncertainty, they should be less likely to engage in the Burden of Proof Fallacy.

It's typically assumed that the burden of proof falls on the plaintiff challenging the default or consensus position, *not* on proponents of the default / consensus position. So, when interacting with someone who holds an atypical view, it's reasonable to say to them, "Mosts experts in the field believe X because they've researched the issue over many years. If you want to claim 'not X,' then the burden of proof rests on you." Unfortunately, this becomes much more difficult is in cases where there doesn't seem to be a default or consensus view. For example, in the case of politics, roughly 50% of citizens might want policy X, and the other 50% might not want policy X. In such a case (assuming X has never been considered before and that there's currently no precedent around it), because there's no consensus view, the burden of proof might fall equally on proponents of both positions.

biases.name: Cherry-picking Fallacy
biases.description: The Cherry-picking Fallacy refers to the use of only a selected subset of available cases, data, or other information when forming or supporting a particular conclusion (while ignoring the rest).
biases.examples: For example, in convincing oneself that there is no need to stop smoking, one might seek out elderly friends and acquaintances who smoke, who are happy to be smoking and don't believe that their health has suffered due to it, and who have lived to at least 70 years of age. By talking only to those people about smoking, one might get an inaccurate impression that there are no dangers associated with the practice.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, offer more representative sources of information. Over the longer-term, it might help to encourage people to develop skills in evaluating different levels of empirical evidence for updating their beliefs.
biases.content:
The Cherry-picking Fallacy refers to the use of only a selected subset of available cases, data, or other information when forming or supporting a particular conclusion (while ignoring the rest).

For example, in convincing oneself that there is no need to stop smoking, one might seek out elderly friends and acquaintances who smoke, who are happy to be smoking and don’t believe that their health has suffered due to it, and who have lived to at least 70 years of age. By talking only to those people about smoking, one might get an inaccurate impression that there are no dangers associated with the practice.

To overcome this fallacy, offer more representative sources of information. Over the longer-term, it might help to encourage people to develop skills in evaluating different levels of empirical evidence for updating their beliefs.

biases.name: Chronological Snobbery Fallacy
biases.description: The Chronological Snobbery Fallacy is a bias against arguments, thought, or work from historically earlier time periods because they are perceived as having arisen at a "less advanced" time period than the present.
biases.examples: For example, it has been believed that getting enough sleep is beneficial for health for many years; for example, Aristotle reportedly believed that sleep [was important](https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2014/11/a-brief-history-of-sleep/) at a time when lots of inaccurate things were also believed. But this does not make the belief that sleep is important for health an invalid one (indeed, there are many longitudinal studies demonstrating measurable health benefits associated with adequate [but not excessive] levels of sleep).
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, provide counterexamples to show that some old ideas have been validated in modern times or even that some new ideas have been invalidated in favor of old ones. Even in cases where the conclusions of earlier thinkers were wrong, show that those thinkers reasoned as well as could possibly be expected given the knowledge and observational instruments of their time.

biases.name: Circumstantial Ad Hominem
biases.description: Circumstantial Ad Hominem is an attempt to discredit a claim or argument by pointing out that the advocate's circumstances predispose them to have an interest in their claim.
biases.examples: For example, one friend may try to convince another friend to stop their unhealthy habit of smoking when they drink. The friend may respond, "Of course you want me to stop smoking---you just want me to stop leaving you in the club whenever I go outside to smoke."

biases.name: Conjunction Fallacy
biases.description: The Conjunction Fallacy is a logical reasoning fallacy wherein someone assigns a lower probability to an event occurring in general than to the event occurring in combination with another event (in "conjunction" with another event).
biases.experimentalEvidence:
In one experiment, subjects were presented with the following scenario: Linda is 31 years old, single, outspoken, and very bright. She majored in philosophy. As a student, she was deeply concerned with issues of discrimination and social justice, and also participated in anti-nuclear demonstrations.

Which is more probable?

1. Linda is a bank teller.
2. Linda is a bank teller and is active in the feminist movement.

85% of those asked chose option 2. However, the probability of two events occurring together (in "conjunction") is always less than or equal to the probability of either one occurring alone. But in another study, the question was rephrased in a more concrete format, and participants were likely to get the answer right. This demonstrates that it may be a result of poor word choice, rather than bias, that causes subjects to create unrealistic associations.

For example, someone might believe that it's more likely that they'll draw *two* aces from a deck of cards than that they'll draw just a *single* ace.

One can also see this fallacy present in conspiracism (in addition to other fallacies), where proponents of a particular conspiracy believe that it's more likely that many outlandish events occurred than that a few mundane events occurred. For example, one common feature of conspiracism is the belief in a vast "cover-up." This requires one to believe that hundreds, thousands, or even millions of people cooperated to hide a highly significant event. While it's by no means impossible for a cover-up to have occurred, most people know enough about human nature to know that (1) humans have trouble cooperating on such a scale for an extended period of time and (2) that too many humans desire honesty and transparency for such an event to be hidden for long. Real conspiracies do exist, of course; but in general it's rational to prefer the simpler explanation over the more complex, all other things being equal. This preference is called Occam's Razor.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, one could aim for the adoption of a "minimum viable version" of the behavior since it is more likely that people will adopt few and small changes rather than large or many changes. People may fall prey to this fallacy and assume that it'll be easier to adopt many large behavior changes at once rather than just one small change. If they bite off more than they can chew, they'll become frustrated and lose motivation. Therefore, it's probably best to ask people to change the smallest amount possible that still results in adoption of the new, positive behavior.

biases.name: Contrast Effect
biases.description: The Contrast Effect refers to the way in which someone's perception of something (e.g., a particular room temperature) can be distorted (relative to objective measurement or relative to their typical experience) due to simultaneous or recent exposure to something that contrasts with it (e.g., a warmer outside temperature).
biases.examples: For example, if you walk into a room that has a temperature of 70° F after having been outside in sweltering summer heat, the room will feel quite cool and maybe even chilly to you. But if you enter the same room after having been outside in a blizzard, the room will feel warm and cozy. In both cases, the objective temperature of the room is same; only your perception differs because of the room's contrast to your situation immediately prior to entering the room.

biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this effect, invite users to adjust to the new behavior by introducing gradual changes (so that the new behavior doesn't seem like such a dramatic departure from their baseline).
biases.otherNotes: The Contrast Effect pushes in the opposite direction as the Anchoring Bias.
biases.content:
The Contrast Effect refers to the way in which someone’s perception of something (e.g., a particular room temperature) can be distorted (relative to objective measurement or relative to their typical experience) due to simultaneous or recent exposure to something that contrasts with it (e.g., a warmer outside temperature).

For example, if you walk into a room that has a temperature of 70° F after having been outside in sweltering summer heat, the room will feel quite cool and maybe even chilly to you. But if you enter the same room after having been outside in a blizzard, the room will feel warm and cozy. In both cases, the objective temperature of the room is same; only your perception differs because of the room’s contrast to your situation immediately prior to entering the room.

To overcome this effect, invite users to adjust to the new behavior by introducing gradual changes (so that the new behavior doesn’t seem like such a dramatic departure from their baseline).
