biases.name: Correlation Implies Causation Fallacy
biases.description: The Correlation Implies Causation Fallacy is the assumption that correlation between two variables automatically implies that one causes the other.
biases.examples: For example, "Our research has shown that there's a strong correlation between recreational drug use and mental health issues. Therefore, using recreational drugs causes mental health problems." (This is a fallacious conclusion because causation might run the other way around: it might be the case that having mental health issues causes a person to use recreational drugs more. Or it could be the case that both variables are caused by a third (unknown) variable.)
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, a necessary (but perhaps not sufficient) step would be to explain the distinct concepts of correlation and causation and the differences between them. Show examples where the causal arrow was later shown to be the reverse of its initial assignment, or where two correlated variables were shown to be caused by a third variable.

biases.name: Denomination Effect
biases.description: The Denomination Effect is a theoretical cognitive bias wherein people tend to be more likely to spend a given amount of money if it is composed of smaller individual sums than if it is composed of larger individual sums.
biases.examples: For example, if someone passes a bakery, they might be more likely to buy 5 items that cost $1 each than 1 item that costs $5.
biases.benevolentHelper: To leverage this effect, it might help to ask people to donate to a cause in small bills, or to invite charitable donations in locations where people are likely to have loose change.
biases.content:
The Denomination Effect is a theoretical cognitive bias wherein people tend to be more likely to spend a given amount of money if it is composed of smaller individual sums than if it is composed of larger individual sums.

For example, if someone passes a bakery, they might be more likely to buy 5 items that cost $1 each than 1 item that costs $5.

To leverage this effect, it might help to ask people to donate to a cause in small bills, or to invite charitable donations in locations where people are likely to have loose change.

biases.name: Disjunction Fallacy
biases.description: The Disjunction Fallacy refers to an error in probabilistic reasoning whereby people estimate that the probability of an event happening exceeds the probability of *either* that event *or* another event happening. The probability that *either* event (A or B) occurs will always be larger than the individual probabilities of A occurring or of B occurring.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Further evidence that the Representativeness Heuristic may be causal to the Disjunction Fallacy comes from Bar-Hillel and Neter (1986). They found that people judge a person who is highly representative of being a statistics major (e.g., highly intelligent, does math competitions) as being more likely to be a statistics major than a social sciences major (superset of statistics), but they do not think that he is more likely to be a Hebrew language major than a humanities major (superset of Hebrew language). Thus, only when the person seems highly representative of a category is that category judged as more probable than its superordinate category. For example, the probability of being either a physics or a biology major is at least as likely as being a physics major, if not more likely. However, when a personality description (data) seems to be very representative of a physics major (e.g., pocket protector) over a biology major, people judge that it is more likely for this person to be a physics major than a natural sciences major (which is a superset of physics). These incorrect appraisals remained even in the face of losing real money in bets on probabilities.

To overcome this fallacy, it might help to point it out, to provide counterexamples, or to explain the math underpinning it.

biases.name: Division Fallacy
biases.description: The Division Fallacy is a logical reasoning fallacy wherein statements about a category (e.g., the characteristics of a group of people) are assumed to apply to some or all parts of that category (e.g., to individual people in the group). The assumption can be fallacious either (1) because individuals in a group exhibit variations of traits or behaviors around an average, or (2) because the group exhibits an emergent property that is otherwise exhibited by none of the members individually. See also: Ecological Fallacy.
biases.examples:
For example: "Democrats want higher taxes on the wealthy. John is a Democrat. Therefore, John wants higher taxes on the wealthy." (Perhaps John differs from his fellow Democrats on that particular issue even if Democrats as a group want higher taxes on the wealthy.)

Another example: "Consciousness is something brains do. Brains are made of cells. Therefore, each brain cell must be conscious." (Perhaps consciousness is an emergent property that results from the behavior of a population of brain cells that are each *not* conscious.)

biases.name: Ecological Fallacy
biases.description: The Ecological Fallacy refers to the fallacious assumption that individual members of a group possess the average characteristics of the group at large. This fallacy is one type of Division Fallacy that occurs specifically in statistics, where one infers from statistical data that an individual shares the group's average traits.
biases.examples: For example, a prospective employer might learn that a job candidate graduated from a high school whose students are known to have low average performance on national tests. They might then assume that the job candidate would have performed poorly on national tests simply because they come from that high school.

biases.name: Fallacy of Composition
biases.description: The Fallacy of Composition refers to the assumption that something is true of the whole simply because it is true of some part of the whole (or even of every proper part of the whole). See also: Hasty Generalization.
biases.examples:
For example, someone may claim that "Most individual people would be better off if they saved a lot more money. Therefore, if everyone saved a lot more money, we would all be better off."

As another example, regularly practicing mindfulness meditation has been shown in multiple studies to produce mental health benefits, but this does not imply that regular mindfulness meditation would benefit everyone. For instance, some subpopulations with mental health concerns (e.g., dissociative identity disorder) may not experience the benefits that other meditators experience. Those people may then be disappointed or actively harmed in their attempt to start and continue a meditation app aimed at the general population (unless they adapt the behavior and their way of enacting it to suit their particular needs).
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this bias, it may help to point this out. This fallacy might be particularly relevant for people who differ significantly from the majority of people who engage in a given behavior. The same benefits and risks that apply to a large subgroup (e.g., neurotypical individuals without mental illness) may not apply to subpopulations of people who differ in meaningful ways from the majority. This might lead people in that subpopulation to form unrealistic expectations, distorted risk/benefit evaluations, unrealistic plans, and unwarranted optimism (or pessimism) regarding their ability to maintain the behavior once they have started it. For subgroups that differ in meaningful ways from the rest of the population, it may help to recognize those differences. This might help the subpopulation to more realistically plan, think about, enact, and maintain the behavior (perhaps using different strategies from the rest of the population).

biases.name: Fallacy of the Undistributed Middle
biases.description: The fallacy of the Undistributed Middle is a logical fallacy about the relationships between categories or assertions. It has the following form: "All Zs are As. Y is an A. So Y is a Z." The fallacy is the assumption that the third statement follows from the previous two, but it does not.
biases.examples:
For example: "All fire-breathing rabbits live on Mars. Sebastian lives on Mars, so Sebastian must be a fire-breathing rabbit."

Another example: "All Crossfitters are in good shape. Ashley is in good shape, so she must do Crossfit."

biases.name: Focusing Effect
biases.description: The Focusing Effect (or Focusing Illusion) refers to a cognitive bias wherein people place too much importance on one piece of information or one aspect of an event (especially the aspect they happen to be thinking about) when drawing a conclusion or predicting an outcome. (Note that this bias relates to the way in which someone thinks about something, making it distinct from Attentional Bias, which relates to specific features of the environment.)
biases.experimentalEvidence: In one experiment, when predicting relative happiness of Californians to themselves, Midwesterners predicted that Californians were more happy overall, because they were focusing on positive factors like the weather, while ignoring negative factors like crime rate.
biases.examples: For example, when deciding whether to join a particular gym, someone may focus on salient information presented to them in a gym flyer. They may thereby neglect other details that should be factored into their decision (such as the travel time to the gym, the alternative options available to them, the cost of this gym relative to other options, and so on).
biases.benevolentHelper: To leverage this effect, it might help to draw people's attention to the positive aspects of the new behavior and the benefits of adopting the new behavior. Similarly, draw their attention to the negative aspects of the old behavior and the costs of the old behavior.

To leverage this effect, it might help to draw people’s attention to the positive aspects of the new behavior and the benefits of adopting the new behavior. Similarly, draw their attention to the negative aspects of the old behavior and the costs of the old behavior.

biases.name: Forer (or Barnum) Effect
biases.description: The Forer Effect refers to a tendency for people to ascribe high levels of accuracy to a description of their personality that is presented as being tailored to them, despite the fact that it is vague enough to apply to a wide range of people.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In 1948, psychologist Bertram R. Forer gave a personality test to his students. He told his students they were each receiving a unique personality analysis that was based on the test's results and to rate their analysis on a scale of 0 (very poor) to 5 (excellent) on how well it applied to themselves. In reality, each received the same analysis. On average, the rating was 4.26, but only after the ratings were turned in was it revealed that each student had received identical copies assembled by Forer from various horoscopes.

biases.name: Framing Effect
biases.description: The Framing Effect refers to a phenomenon whereby the ways that the benefits and costs of various options are emphasized affects the way people choose among those options.
biases.experimentalEvidence: A set of experiments on framing indicated that different phrasing affected participants' responses to a question about a disease prevention strategy. Two options were presented to subjects, both describing the same statistical outcome, but one focused on the number of deaths, while the other focused on number of lives. Participants were much more likely to choose the option that "saved" lives.
biases.examples: For example, someone may be considering whether to undergo joint replacement surgery. They may reach a different conclusion regarding whether to go ahead with it depending on whether they are told that there is a (for example) 0.5% chance of death from surgical complications (negative framing) or that there is a 99.5% chance of survival (positive framing).
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome and/or to leverage this effect, carefully consider and modify the ways that costs and benefits are emphasized when encouraging someone to adopt a new, positive behavior.

biases.name: Gambler's Fallacy
biases.description: Gambler's Fallacy refers to a belief that, in a series of randomly occurring events, if one event happened less frequently than expected in the recent past, then it is more likely to happen in the future (or vice versa). (Note that this differs from Regression Toward the Mean because part of the Gambler's Fallacy is the assumption that the future "compensates" for the past.)
biases.examples: For example, suppose that someone noticed that they had lost a large sum of money during the previous six months of gambling. They might expect that the next six months should involve *gaining* approximately similar amounts of money to "balance out" the previous losses. They might then conclude that they should not abandon their gambling habit, despite others around them perhaps advising them to do so.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this falacy, it might help to point it out and explain why the reasoning is flawed. (To spot the fallacy in the first place, it might help to be on the lookout for cases where someone has concluded that a trend in one direction in a random process will be followed by a trend in the opposite direction soon afterward.)

biases.description: The Illicit Major Fallacy is a logical reasoning fallacy about the relationships between categories or assertions. For the purpose of explaining this fallacy, let's imagine there are three categories of things labeled as "A," "B," and "C." The Illicit Major Fallacy has the following form: "All A are B. There is a fallacious assumption here that the third statement follows from the first two, but it does not (e.g., B could be a larger category than A, so just because no C are A, that doesn't preclude things in category C from belonging to category B).

In other words, Illusion-of-Truth Memory Bias causes people to be more likely to believe a familiar statement than an unfamiliar one.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this bias, it may help to identify when it occurs and to question any conclusions based upon it. The results revealed that the staff had overestimated the number of female seniority staff and underestimated the number of male senior staff. biases.name: Incomplete Comparison Fallacy
biases.description: Incomplete Comparison Fallacy refers to the use of a claim containing incomplete information, which therefore cannot be refuted.
biases.examples: An example would be the claim by a manufacturer that, "Our product is longer lasting!" (This cannot be assessed because they have not said which products form the comparison group in their claim.)
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, it may help to point out when it occurs and encourage further information-seeking before drawing conclusions about the product(s) or item(s) in question. Intervention designers should also avoid this fallacy in the first place, being careful to make complete, transparent, and accurate comparisons between options (e.g., when presenting information about why it may be beneficial to engage in a desired behavior). Although it might increase the probability that someone desires, plans for, implements, and maintains a positive behavior, engaging in this fallacy could be misleading (and if so, unethical) and would come with the potential to backfire for those who notice the fallacy (through Argument from Fallacy/Inoculation Effect).

biases.content:
Information Bias in psychology refers to a cognitive bias towards seeking further information, even when additional information is not relevant or required for choosing one’s next course of action.

For example: You’re shopping for a new guitar. After narrowing the search down to three different models, you start looking at technical specifications for each model. All three offer comparable hardware, so you start to look at other features of each instrument. Each is made of a different type of wood, so you start to investigate the sonic properties of each type. You then look into each manufacturer’s sourcing of the wood, and then the conditions under which the relevant tree grows, and then into the life cycle of each tree. Before you know it, you’ve spent your entire evening reading about mahogany genera.

To overcome this bias, if people keep asking for more information than is necessary for them to adopt the new behavior, gently point out to them that they have all the necessary information and that they may just be trying to find ways to avoid adopting the new behavior.

biases.name: Ingroup Bias
biases.description: Ingroup Bias refers to a tendency for people to give preferential treatment to those perceived to be members of their ingroup.
biases.experimentalEvidence:
Robert Cialdini and his research team looked at the number of university T-shirts being worn on college campuses following either a win or loss at the football game. Not surprisingly, the Monday after a win there were more T-shirts being worn, on average, than following a loss. [The next sentences are from the original description column and seem to be expanding on the concept rather than only describing it.] The need to improve self esteem may be one cause of this bias: individuals will find a reason, no matter how insignificant, to prove to themselves why their group is superior. By having a more positive impression of individuals in the ingroup, individuals are able to boost their own self-esteem as members of that group.

The bias may lead to intergroup aggression, competition, and prejudice.

The Just-World Phenomenon refers to a tendency for people to see the world as a just place (which is thought to arise from a desire to see it as such). As a result, when they witness an otherwise inexplicable injustice, they may rationalize it by searching for ways in which the victim can be perceived as deserving it.

To try to overcome this phenomenon after someone has experienced a behavioral failure or slip-up, it may be helpful to discourage people from assigning blame or to point out examples of times when they have succeeded. To leverage this phenomenon, one could highlight the ways in which someone has “earned” their success through hard work (rather than through luck and circumstances).

biases.benevolentHelper:
To try to overcome this fallacy, it could help to point out when it occurs and to encourage the person to notice the uncertainties involved in the situation at hand. Otherwise, the fallacy could cause people to prematurely stop searching for information about how to start and maintain the behavior because they assume they have enough information already. 

To overcome this fallacy in the longer-term, one could encourage the person to practice probabilistic thinking, with particular attention being paid to realizing that they should have some uncertainty in every belief that they form. For example, one could note that, although one can be sure that one is currently having thoughts (if one is thinking about this idea, then they must be thinking), this is probably the only thing about which one can really be sure. Beyond that, there is some degree of uncertainty in almost every statement. It might also help to practice fostering epistemic humility. To do this, one could practice (1) realizing that they may be wrong and (2) using evidence and reasoning to routinely subject statements and beliefs to scrutiny (before accepting them).

biases.name: Observer-Expectancy Effect
biases.description: The Observer-Expectancy Effect (also known as the Experimenter's Effect or the Expectation Effect) refers to an effect whereby someone expects a particular result (e.g., in an experiment or dataset) and, owing to this expectation, subconsciously manipulates an experiment or misinterprets data in order to find that result.
biases.examples:
For example, a police officer may (subconsciously) believe that black people are morally inferior to white people and may therefore (subconsciously) arrest black people at a higher rate than white people. Later, they might look at their arrest records and notice that they've arrested black people at a higher rate than white people, and they might feel that their worldview is justified (even if they never explicate their own beliefs to themselves). 

As another example, this might manifest in a behavior change context as a person who has an expectation that they'll fail to adopt a new behavior. They may sabotage themselves or misinterpret the actual outcomes as manifestations of failure.

biases.experimentalEvidence: Spranca, Minsk, and Baron extended the omission bias to judgments of morality of choices. In one scenario, John, a tennis player, would be facing a tough opponent the next day in a decisive match. John knows that his opponent is allergic to a food substance. Subjects were presented with two conditions: John recommends the food containing the allergen to hurt his opponent's performance, or the opponent himself orders the allergenic food, and John says nothing. A majority of people judged that John's action of recommending the allergenic food as being more immoral than John's inaction of not informing the opponent of the allergenic substance.

biases.name: Optimism Bias
biases.description: Optimism Bias is the tendency to be unduly optimistic about the probability of future positive and negative events (i.e., overestimating the probability of the former while underestimating the probability of the latter).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Armor and Taylor review a number of studies that have found optimism bias in different kinds of judgment. These include: - Second-year MBA students overestimated the number of job offers they would receive and their starting salary; - Students overestimated the scores they would achieve on exams; - Almost all newlyweds in a US study expected their marriage to last a lifetime, even while aware of divorce statistics; - Professional financial analysts consistently overestimated corporate earnings; - Most smokers believe they are less at risk of developing smoking-related diseases than others who smoke. Companies have exploited this bias by increasing interest rates to punitive rates for any late payment, knowing that overconfidence causes many people to grossly underestimate their odds of making a payment late.

Having optimistic expectations in and of themselves could increase the probability that the person performs better than they would have (had their expectations been lower). This may be desirable as long as the person is aware of the bias and as long as the person's expectations are not so high as to be unrealistic. It may also help to generate more realistic expectations regarding positive and negative outcomes of their behavior change efforts. The person could then generate more realistic plans for starting and continuing a given behavior.

[taken from original description column as these appear less about definitions and more about more in-depth explanations] Pareidolia refers to a phenomenon whereby vague and/or random stimuli are perceived as significant, e.g., seeing images of animals or faces in clouds, the man in the moon, and hearing hidden messages on records played in reverse.

Pareidolia is why we find a "face" when we look at two dots and a line arranged inside of a circle.

Carl Sagan hypothesized that as a survival technique, human beings are "hard-wired" from birth to identify the human face. This allows people to use only minimal details to recognize faces from a distance and in poor visibility, but can also lead them to interpret random images or patterns of light and shade as being faces. The evolutionary advantages of being able to identify friend from foe with split-second accuracy are numerous. For example, prehistoric (and even modern) men and women who accidentally identify an enemy as a friend could face deadly consequences for this mistake. This is only one among many evolutionary pressures responsible for the development of the modern facial recognition capability of modern humans

biases.name: Pseudocertainty Effect
biases.description: The Pseudocertainty Effect refers to a tendency to perceive an outcome as certain despite uncertainty in multi-stage decision-making.
biases.examples: For example, someone may have the goal of learning a new skill by a specific date and might be deciding whether to apply for one of two difficult-to-enter courses teaching that skill. They might only have a 25% chance of gaining entry to either of the options, but they need to decide in advance which of the two they want to apply for: a strictly-structured course or a self-paced one (that would allow them to learn 1.5 times as much material overall). Suppose they believe that by doing the strictly-structured one, they can be ~100% sure to learn the skill by a specific date; on the other hand, they predict only an 80% chance of engaging in the course material associated with the alternative, self-paced course. If they fell prey to the Pseudocertainty Effect, they would opt for the option with the 100% chance of reaching a particular skill level (even if that only allows for two-thirds the level of skill acquisition as the alternative would have).
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome or avoid this effect, when planning a multiple-stage process of behavior change, it might help to sit down and estimate the odds of different outcomes at each stage of a decision-process, taking uncertainties into account at every step. Otherwise, the Pseudocertainty Effect could cause one to overlook the uncertainties associated with reaching relevant milestones on the way to behavior change goals.
biases.otherNotes: Possible Q - present 3 stages of a decision and ask what will most affect the probability of different outcomes... the answer having to do with the first stage will have the most impact in the final result, but may be less flashy/obvious than answers having to do with the 2nd or 3rd stages.

For example, someone may have the goal of learning a new skill by a specific date and might be deciding whether to apply for one of two difficult-to-enter courses teaching that skill. They might only have a 25% chance of gaining entry to either of the options, but they need to decide in advance which of the two they want to apply for: a strictly-structured course or a self-paced one (that would allow them to learn 1.5 times as much material overall). Suppose they believe that by doing the strictly-structured one, they can be ~100% sure to learn the skill by a specific date; on the other hand, they predict only an 80% chance of engaging in the course material associated with the alternative, self-paced course. If they fell prey to the Pseudocertainty Effect, they would opt for the option with the 100% chance of reaching a particular skill level (even if that only allows for two-thirds the level of skill acquisition as the alternative would have).

To overcome or avoid this effect, when planning a multiple-stage process of behavior change, it might help to sit down and estimate the odds of different outcomes at each stage of a decision-process, taking uncertainties into account at every step. Otherwise, the Pseudocertainty Effect could cause one to overlook the uncertainties associated with reaching relevant milestones on the way to behavior change goals.

biases.experimentalEvidence: The US states of New Jersey and Pennsylvania inadvertently ran a real life experiment providing evidence of the Status Quo Bias in the early 1990s. As part of Tort law reform programs, citizens were offered two options for their automotive insurance: an expensive option giving them full right to sue, and a less expensive option with restricted rights to sue. In New Jersey the cheaper option was the default and most citizens selected it, while only a minority chose it in Pennsylvania where the more expensive option was the default. Similar effects have been shown for contributions to retirement plans, choice of internet privacy policies and the decision to become an organ donor.

biases.name: Straw Man Fallacy
biases.description: Straw Man Fallacy refers to the strategy of responding to a weak version of an opponent's position, that they don't actually believe, rather than responding to the opponent's original position (which may have been more difficult to refute).
biases.examples: For example, someone may argue that their chronically tired friend should aim to sleep more than 6 hours per night, and the friend may respond by saying, "I can't sleep all day - I have things to do!" (This would represent a response to a very weak version of the argument (that the person should sleep all day), rather than the original argument, which was simply that they should try sleeping more than 6 hours a night.)

When attempting to overcome this fallacy, the best approach to take might depend on how strongly the person holds their opposing beliefs. If they hold their beliefs strongly, then similar strategies might be useful as those for Wishful Thinking and the Appeal to Consequences Fallacy. In cases where the backfire risk is deemed to be sufficiently low, it may be worth encouraging the person to practice actively considering the reasons that arguments in opposition to their own could actually turn out to be true. An example of this could be trying to find the best ways of supporting an opposing argument, which can be called "steel-manning" the argument ([Mattes, 2020](https://search.informit.com.au/fullText;dn=077923104428244;res=IELENG)).

For example, a woman who has been sexually harassed in the workplace might believe the statement “Most women are sexually harassed in the workplace” merely because she’s had personal experience with sexual harassment. (The statement might still be true, but the belief that it’s true should be a conclusion drawn from the analysis of statistical evidence and not based on mere personal (i.e., anecdotal) experience.)

For example, a person might believe the claim that “everything happens for a reason” because a deceased loved one used to say it all the time, and believing it provides both a way of making sense of the loved one’s death and a way of honoring their memory.

To overcome this bias, ask the person to take the outside view about whatever’s being claimed. In other words, ask them: “What would someone else believe about this claim given that they haven’t had your exact set of experiences?”

To leverage this bias, couch claims in terms that will be significant or meaningful to the target population.
biases.title: Subjective Validation

biases.name: Thinking in Categories / Binary Thinking
biases.description: Thinking in Categories, as its name suggests, involves conceptualizing things into two or more simple categories. When someone conceptualizes a concept as being composed of only two categories (e.g., "good" or "bad," or "right" or "wrong"), this can also be called Binary Thinking. (These kinds of thinking are simpler than continuum thinking, wherein concepts are conceptualized as occurring on a continuum.)
biases.manualKeywords: binary, two, dichotomy, category, continuous, multiple, alternatives
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this bias, it might help to ask people to compare extremes _within_ one of their categories as a way of showing that the category is too simple. For example, if they view all exercise as "hard," ask them whether walking for five minutes is as challenging as running a marathon. Similarly, for all of the items in all categories, one could sort them (along each spectrum) from lowest to highest. It might also help to point out that simple categories often represent a conflation or compression of multiple spectra. For example, the categories of "good" and "bad" might include spectra such as intentions, consequences, social context, and so on.

biases.name: Thought-Terminating Cliché
biases.description: A Thought-Terminating Cliché refers to a saying that is intended to prevent further thought about a given topic.
biases.examples: For example, "It is what it is" can be considered to be a thought-terminating cliché since it encourages disengagement with a topic rather than facilitating discussion of the reasons behind a particular situation.
biases.manualKeywords: thought, terimate, cliche, prevent, stop, topic
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome a thought-terminating cliché, it might help to examine and question it. If the cliché is "Dear leader knows best," then one can ask questions like: Is the leader actually dear to me? Are they the rightful leader? How does the leader know what's best? And does "best" mean best for the leader or best for all of us? Against what theory of morality is "best" measured? What happens if the leader is incapacitated? Is it impossible for someone else to know better than the leader? What are the leader's incentives? What are the incentives of those who are deploying the cliché?

biases.name: Ultimate Attribution Error
biases.description: Ultimate Attribution Error refers to an error whereby someone attributes an outgroup's negative behavior to internal causes like personality traits and positive behavior to external causes - yet they attribute an ingroup's positive behavior to internal causes and negative behavior to external causes.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In his 1976 demonstration, Birt Duncan asked White participants to watch a video of a man shoving another man. One video had a Caucasian male shoving another Caucasian male and a second video had an African American male shoving a Caucasian male. When the participants watched the first video they concluded that the Caucasian male doing the shoving was attributed to having fun (a situational factor), but when they watched the second video they attributed the African American’s behavior to an aggressive personality (Duncan, 1979). The results of Duncan's study demonstrates that ultimate attribution error is more likely to occur when there are negative associations with members of an outgroup due to previous conflict or certain situations that were experienced (Whitley & Kite, 2010).

biases.name: Zero-Risk Bias
biases.description: Zero-risk Bias refers to the cognitive bias favoring opportunities to eliminate rather than mitigate risk. This can become relevant when there are multiple possible courses of action, some of which involve complete elimination of a subcategory of risk and others of which do not. This bias can cause people to irrationally favor options that completely eliminate a subcategory of risk, even if other options come with a greater absolute reduction in risk overall.
biases.experimentalEvidence: This bias has been demonstrated in multiple studies, with its probability of affecting decision-making appearing to depend on the decision-making context and framing (e.g., [Schneider et al., 2017](https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2017-30652-004?casa_token=DoeNW5Pr_h4AAAAA:x2ARETOKfbu36oNRrcd8dgznUGeHhOi5y-XfpqkBuHZ6Ijq7OZy0sUZsk_onyEH3B1idwdM36R9yEdr8XN81p_6F); [Raue & Schneider, 2019](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-11456-5_5)). In one recent study ([Cantarelli, Belle & Belardinelli, 2020](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0734371X18778090?casa_token=SuOajn6vVvgAAAAA%3A-f8cxnU1B4lplrwGne2UrBwLTS6UVgwcmN1kd3J6UimijTGMaq-ZvuzOcmlwIda0g7QXQiw4KPUhuA)), 495 nurses were given a scenario where they were told that an infectious disease had broken out in two developing countries, and that the doses of the perfectly effective vaccination were limited. One intervention plan would save an expected 6,000 lives via partial vaccination coverage in both nations: this plan would reduce deaths from 8,000 to 4,000 in one country and from 4,000 to 2,000 in the other country. The other intervention plan would save an expected 5,000 lives, but entailed a full vaccination coverage in one nation (from 4,000 to 0 deaths, so zero risk of death from that disease in that country) and a partial vaccination coverage in the other nation (from 8,000 to 7,000 in that country). Approximately 29% of the sample appeared to be affected by zero-risk bias, favoring the scenario that involved complete elimination of risk in one of the countries, despite that option saving 1,000 fewer lives overall.

However, Medicine A has causes side effect X in 1 out of every 25 people and side effect Y in 1 out of every 10 people, though it can never cause both side effects in one person. Medicine B causes side effect X in 1 out of every 5 people, but does not cause side effect Y in anyone. Assuming that you believe side effects X and Y to be equally undesirable, which medicine do you take?

biases.content:
Zero-risk Bias refers to the cognitive bias favoring opportunities to eliminate rather than mitigate risk. This can become relevant when there are multiple possible courses of action, some of which involve complete elimination of a subcategory of risk and others of which do not. This bias can cause people to irrationally favor options that completely eliminate a subcategory of risk, even if other options come with a greater absolute reduction in risk overall.

For example, someone who is attempting to decrease the environmental harms associated with their lifestyle might focus on completely eliminating their use of plastic straws (because this would reduce their production of plastic straw waste to zero) while neglecting other actions that they could take to reduce the harm they produce to a much greater degree (even though risks in other categories couldn’t be reduced to zero, and might not be able to be estimated precisely).

To overcome this bias when it is suspected to be counterproductively influencing behavior, it might help to point it out and to encourage the person to reevaluate the situation. Over the longer-term, it might help to practice probabilistic reasoning. It might also help to write down the estimated risks associated with each of the possible outcomes/choices being considered, along with the predicted risks following different actions.
biases.title: Zero-Risk Bias

examples.description: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...the advertisement she saw hadn't mentioned the potentially life-changing benefits of therapy for anxiety.
Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...a friend hadn't described to him the suffering of animals and the environmental damage caused by factory farming.

Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't realized that her behavior was inconsistent; she went into this line of work to help the world, so why would she put it at risk by publishing potentially dangerous research on how to make viruses more virulent?

substeps.title: 3. Intends to engage in the behavior
substeps.description:
Even if we desire adopting a new behavior, we're very unlikely to actually do so unless we ourselves predict that we will conduct that behavior at specific times, in specific situations, or within a certain time frame. There are a variety of reasons we may not intend to engage in a behavior even when we find the behavior desirable:
  1. Busyness—e.g., we may think "I don't have time in my life right now to start a behavior like this"
  2. Delay—e.g., we may think "I'll get around to doing this eventually"
  3. Lack of Self-Efficacy—e.g., we may think "I'll probably fail if I try to engage in this behavior"
  4. Ambiguity—e.g., we may think "I don't know how to get started"
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...she hadn't made a plan to search online therapist directories right after work that evening.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...he hadn't decided that, from that moment forward, he wouldn't eat meat again.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't decided that, from then on, each time she had a new project idea she would consider its societal risks before committing to it.
substeps.question: How can you help the target person or population to anticipate or to plan to adopt the target behavior during a given time frame or whenever they are in a specific context?

biases.name: Actor-Observer Asymmetry
biases.description: The Actor-Observer Asymmetry occurs when people subconsciously attribute behavior to different causes depending on whether they're the person performing the behavior (the *actor*) or merely a witness (an *observer*). When assessing their own behavior as actors, people tend to emphasize the influence of the situation on their behavior and downplay the influence of their own personality or character. When assessing others' behavior as observers, the reverse is true: people's assessment of others' behavior tends to emphasize the influence of personality or character on the behavior and downplay the influence of the situation. See also: Fundamental Attribution Error.
biases.experimentalEvidence: This has been demonstrated in studies by differentiating between actors' and observers' explanations in the following way: people's explanations were separated into theoretically meaningful distinctions (e.g., reasons vs. causal history of reason explanations). The responses were categorized, and the differences emerged.
biases.examples: For example: "I haven't been able to get into the habit of going to the gym because life has just been so busy lately. Every day, I go to work, come home and spend a few minutes with my kids and spouse, cook dinner, and work on remodeling our back porch. I don't have time to go to the gym! But I'm totally unlike my spouse: they avoid the gym out of pure laziness."
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this bias, it might help to ask people to consider how a friend, loved one, or ideal person would have behaved in the same situation. For example, if a person skipped gym day because of a thunderstorm that day, ask them whether or not their gym buddy also missed that day because of the storm. By comparing their actions against other people in identical situations, they might see that the context was less relevant than they supposed and that their character was more relevant than they realized.
biases.content:
The Actor-Observer Asymmetry occurs when people subconsciously attribute behavior to different causes depending on whether they’re the person performing the behavior (the actor) or merely a witness (an observer). When assessing their own behavior as actors, people tend to emphasize the influence of the situation on their behavior and downplay the influence of their own personality or character. When assessing others’ behavior as observers, the reverse is true: people’s assessment of others’ behavior tends to emphasize the influence of personality or character on the behavior and downplay the influence of the situation. See also: Fundamental Attribution Error.

For example: “I haven’t been able to get into the habit of going to the gym because life has just been so busy lately. Every day, I go to work, come home and spend a few minutes with my kids and spouse, cook dinner, and work on remodeling our back porch. I don’t have time to go to the gym! But I’m totally unlike my spouse: they avoid the gym out of pure laziness.”

To overcome this bias, it might help to ask people to consider how a friend, loved one, or ideal person would have behaved in the same situation. For example, if a person skipped gym day because of a thunderstorm that day, ask them whether or not their gym buddy also missed that day because of the storm. By comparing their actions against other people in identical situations, they might see that the context was less relevant than they supposed and that their character was more relevant than they realized.
biases.title: Actor-Observer Asymmetry

biases.name: Affirming the Consequent Fallacy
biases.description: This fallacy has the form: "If P, then Q. Q. Therefore P." The mistake lies in the assumption that if P implies Q, then Q implies P.
biases.examples: For example: "Everyone who does Crossfit is in very fit. Alice is in very fit, so she must do Crossfit."
biases.manualKeywords: after, consequent, imply, implication, if, then
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, show that there are other ways to arrive at the current state of affairs by giving concrete counterexamples. In the example above ("Everyone who does Crossfit is in very fit. Alice is in very fit, so she must do Crossfit."), it's possible that Alice has gotten fit through some other means than Crossfit; perhaps she does P90X, for example.
biases.content:
This fallacy has the form: “If P, then Q. Q. Therefore P.” The mistake lies in the assumption that if P implies Q, then Q implies P.

For example: “Everyone who does Crossfit is in very fit. Alice is in very fit, so she must do Crossfit.”

To overcome this fallacy, show that there are other ways to arrive at the current state of affairs by giving concrete counterexamples. In the example above (“Everyone who does Crossfit is in very fit. Alice is in very fit, so she must do Crossfit.”), it’s possible that Alice has gotten fit through some other means than Crossfit; perhaps she does P90X, for example.

biases.name: Ambiguity Effect
biases.description: The Ambiguity Effect is a cognitive bias wherein decision-makers tend to select options for which the probability of a favorable outcome is known instead of an option for which the probability of a favorable outcome is unknown or ambiguous.
biases.examples:
For example: "I know that if I pick Door #1, I have a 15% chance of winning a moderately good prize. I also know that if I pick Door #2, I'll win a prize, but I don't know how good the prize will be or what the chances of winning are. I guess I'll pick Door #1!"

Another example: "I want to invest in Company #1 because it has a proven track record of success...even though that investment will have a low ROI and I'm not absolutely in love with their product. I'd rather do that than invest in Company #2 because, even though Company #2 has a product I like, I just don't know anything about them!"

Another example: Someone might choose a fixed-rate mortgage (where the interest rate doesn't change) over a variable-rate mortgage (where the interest rate fluctuates with the market) even if the variable-rate mortgage saves them money.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this effect, it might help to report the likelihood of all outcomes wherever possible. It might also help to develop an intuition for the probabilities by comparing them to commonly-known outcomes.

biases.name: Denying the Antecedent Fallacy
biases.description: Denying the Antecedent Fallacy is a logical fallacy about the relationships between categories or assertions. It takes the form: "If P, then Q. Not P. Therefore, not Q." The fallacy is the assumption that the conclusion follows from the premises, although it actually doesn't follow (e.g., because there can be cases of Q that are not preceded by P). The fact that Q always follows *if* P is true does not imply that Q must always be preceded by P.
biases.examples: For example, "If you go to the gym, you'll get fit. You don't go to the gym, so you can't possibly get fit!"
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, it might help to point this out and to show why this is a fallacy. By pointing out the flaw in this reasoning, it may be possible to open up a more comprehensive range of possible plans that the person could form (e.g., to meet their behavioral goals). Also, provide counterexamples to show that (to use the example from above) it's possible to get fit *without* going to the gym.

biases.name: Fallacy of the Single Cause
biases.description: The Fallacy of the Single Cause refers to a fallacious assumption that there is a single cause of an outcome (whereas in reality, the outcome may instead be attributable to a number of only jointly sufficient causes).
biases.examples: For example, suppose that someone was overweight and decided to work toward returning to a healthy weight range by engaging in regular physical activity, consulting with a dietician, and adjusting their caloric intake over a two-year period. And suppose that these changes were jointly sufficient for the person to return to a healthy weight range. Their friend might attribute this change to the person's physical activity alone, without realizing that it was due to several jointly sufficient causes.

biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, it might help to point out the flawed reasoning. One way to do this might be by sharing evidence demonstrating that the phenomenon in question would not have happened if some of the jointly sufficient causes were not present. Noting when this fallacy is occurring could be particularly helpful at various stages of behavioral change. For example, someone may need assistance forming realistic plans to start the behavior, forming realistic expectations about the effects of the behavior and its advantages over alternative behaviors, or understanding the sufficient conditions for maintenance of the behavior. Questioning one's assumptions and developing a better understanding of the sufficient causes of specific outcomes might help with forming more realistic plans, which should increase the chances of successfully starting and maintaining the behavior in question.

biases.name: False Analogy Fallacy
biases.description: The False Analogy Fallacy refers to a fallacious assumption that if two things are similar in some ways, and if one of those things has a certain property, then the other thing will also have that property. It has the following form: "A and B are similar in some ways. A has property X; therefore, B has property X." If B does not have property X, then this represents an example of the False Analogy Fallacy.
biases.examples: For example, suppose that Alice observes that Bob has decided to engage in the same spin class as her. After they talk, it becomes apparent that both of them value fitness and have chosen to increase their activity levels. Alice might then assume that because they have some things in common, she will automatically have other characteristics in common with Bob (e.g., she may assume they both need to meet the goal in the same way and will run into the same challenges).
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, point it out and provide counterexamples. It might also help to form a more realistic appraisal of the situation in question via the collection of information from a wider range of (non-anecdotal) sources. This might then facilitate more realistic plans for commencing and continuing the behavior.

biases.name: Illusion of Asymmetric Insight
biases.description: The Illusion of Asymmetric Insight refers to a person's perception that they know more about their peers than their peers know about them. The same term can also be applied when a group believes they know more about other groups than those groups know about them.
biases.manualKeywords: symmetric, asymmetric, insight, perception, peer, group
biases.benevolentHelper: To try to overcome this illusion, one could encourage people not to assume that they are can easily discern all there is to know about their peers (e.g., when they perceive other people as breezing through a behavior change). In turn, this could lead them to form inaccurate beliefs about how easy the behavior change is (which might be motivating in the short-term, but which might cause unrealistic plans to be made, which might reduce the chance of the behavior being successfully engaged in and maintained).

biases.name: Overconfidence Effect
biases.description: The Overconfidence Effect refers to a cognitive bias whereby someone's confidence in their answers to questions exceeds their level of accuracy
biases.experimentalEvidence: The Overconfidence Effect is one of the most important and well-studied cognitive biases in psychology and behavioral economics. Overconfidence has been studied in three different ways: 1. Overestimation of one's performance, ability, level of control, or rate of work; 2. An inflated belief that one is better than others, or overplacement; and 3. An excessive belief in the truth and accuracy of one’s beliefs, or overprecision. One is example is shown in a spelling task, where subjects were correct about 80% of the time when they were "100% certain." Put another way, the error rate was 20% when subjects expected it to be 0%.

biases.name: Perfectionist Fallacy
biases.description: Perfectionist Fallacy refers to the fallacious assumption that the only permissible option is perfection, and anything less than that should be rejected.
biases.examples: For example, in response to encouragement to join a gym, someone might say, "What's the use of trying? I could never have perfectly sculpted abs."

biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this fallacy, one could respectfully encourage the person to engage in more realistic reasoning, perhaps by providing examples of outcomes that are desirable, despite not being perfect. biases.name: Trait Ascription Bias
biases.description: Trait Ascription Bias is a bias wherein people view themselves as relatively variable in terms of personality, behavior, and mood, despite viewing others as much more predictable. It has been hypothesized that this may arise because our own internal states are directly observable and available to us (which is, of course, not the case for others' mental states).
biases.examples: For example, someone may observe that a certain behavior (e.g., aerobic exercise) tends to produce positive mood changes in other people. However, they may believe that the effects they experience following the behavior will be less predictable, owing to their (seemingly) more complex and varying range of affective states.

biases.name: Attentional Bias
biases.description: Attentional Bias occurs when some information or evidence holds a disproportionate amount of a person's attention because of that person's environment or history.
biases.experimentalEvidence:
In studies using the dot-probe paradigm, patients who suffered from chronic ailments such as anxiety were more likely to focus on information or stimuli representing their concerns (e.g., in the case of anxiety, patients were more likely to focus on worried facial expressions).

A within-subjects bias occurs when an individual displays greater bias toward one type of information (e.g., painful faces) when compared to different types of information (e.g., neutral faces). Alternatively, a between-subjects bias occurs when one group of participants displays greater bias than another group of participants (e.g., chronic pain patients showed greater bias towards painful expressions than did healthy control participants).

biases.name: Context Effect in Memory
biases.description: Context-dependent memory refers to improved retrieval (or recall) of specific memories if the context present at the time of memory retrieval is the same as the context present at the time the memory was first stored (or encoded).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Psychologists that have researched context dependent recall include Abernathy (1940), as well as Godden & Baddeley (1975). Context-dependent cues are dependent on the environment and situation. Memory retrieval can be facilitated or triggered by replication of the context in which the memory was encoded. Such conditions include weather, company, location, smelling a particular odor, hearing a certain song, and even taste can sometimes act as a cue. For example, students sometimes fail to recall diligently studied material when an examination room's environmental conditions differ significantly from the room or place where learning occurred. To improve learning and recall, it is recommended that students should study under conditions that closely resemble an examination.

substeps.title: 5. Believes attempting each action will help achieve a goal
substeps.description:
We're very unlikely to attempt a specific action if we don't think that attempting it will help us to achieve a desired outcome. We may fail to believe that attempting an action will help us achieve a desired outcome for various reasons:
  1. Lack of Perceived Connection to Goal—e.g., we may think "I don't see how carrying out this action will actually help me achieve my goal"
  2. Lack of Self-Efficacy—e.g., we may think "I'll probably fail if I try to perform this action"
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...she hadn't come to believe that visiting the therapist would help to alleviate her anxiety.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...he hadn't been convinced that being vegetarian would help to reduce animal suffering and mitigate climate change.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't seen from the example set by a colleague that it was possible to improve the safety of research like her own.

biases.name: Base Rate Neglect
biases.description: Base Rate Neglect, or Base Rate Fallacy or Bias, is an error that occurs when the conditional probability of some hypothesis H, given some evidence E, is assessed without taking into account the "base rate" or "prior probability" of H and the total probability of evidence E.
biases.experimentalEvidence:
In some experiments, students were asked to estimate the grade point averages (GPAs) of hypothetical students. When given relevant statistics about GPA distribution, students tended to ignore them if given descriptive information about the particular student, even if the new descriptive information was obviously of little or no relevance to school performance. 

Psychologists attempted to explain this finding in terms of the Representativeness Heuristic. Others have argued that some attributional biases like the Fundamental Attribution Error are instances of the Base Rate Fallacy: people underutilize "consensus information" (the "base rate") about how others behaved in similar situations and instead prefer simpler dispositional attributions.
biases.benevolentHelper:
To overcome this phenomenon, it may help to support people to increase their weighting of background or contextual information in a given situation. 

Example #1: It is known that 1 in 10,000 people have a certain kind of cancer, and it is also known that a test for that kind of cancer performed on 10,000 people will yield 100 positives; therefore, the test has a false positive rate of 99 out of 10,000. If a doctor performs the test on a patient but fails to consider the test's false positive rate and only considers the rate of cancer in the general population, then she will very likely misdiagnose a positive result from the test as being true when it is much more likely that a positive result is false. 

Example #2: It is known that only a very small percentage of startups last longer than two years. Someone might be considering investing in a startup that seems to have been doing well during the two months that it has been running. They may be so impressed with the startup team that they are sure that it'll last longer than two years. However, this confidence is likely to be misplaced given the background information that most startups fail.

You don't necessarily have to bring math into it (as in Example #1), but it's still useful to help people find ways to evaluate their scenario-specific information relative to the broader context (as in Example #2). To develop a more intuitive understanding of the math involved in situations like the one described in Example #1, watch [this explainer video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lG4VkPoG3ko).
biases.ideasForTesting:
Provide person with statistics about number of people in U.S. living with HIV and the chances of a false positive on an HIV test. Then ask the % chance that a randomly selected person in the U.S. has HIV if he/she tests positive. 

Can we make a more real world type example out of the same problem?

To overcome this phenomenon, it may help to support people to increase their weighting of background or contextual information in a given situation.

Example #1: It is known that 1 in 10,000 people have a certain kind of cancer, and it is also known that a test for that kind of cancer performed on 10,000 people will yield 100 positives; therefore, the test has a false positive rate of 99 out of 10,000. biases.name: Belief Bias
biases.description: Belief Bias refers to a tendency to base one's degree of support for a set of arguments on the perceived believability of the *conclusion*, rather than how strongly the presented arguments support that conclusion.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In a series of experiments, subjects were presented with deductive arguments (in each of which a series of premises and a conclusion are given) and asked to indicate if each conclusion necessarily follows from the premises given. In other words, the subjects are asked to make an evaluation of logical validity. The subjects, however, exhibited belief bias when they rejected valid arguments with unbelievable conclusions, and endorsed invalid arguments with believable conclusions. It seems that instead of following directions and assessing logical validity, the subjects based their assessments on personal beliefs.

biases.content:
The Clustering Illusion refers to a tendency to see patterns or clusters in samples drawn from random distributions.

For example, a person might think they notice that they tend to win more at a casino when wearing a certain tie, so they choose to wear a tie the next time they go to the casino, and they end up losing a lot of money.

To overcome this illusion, it might help to show examples of people inaccurately finding patterns where they don’t exist. It may also help to remember that pattern identification is nothing more than an intuition unless a clear causal link can be established (or the pattern is unlikely enough to be due to chance that the possibility it is due to random variation can be ruled out).

biases.name: Confirmation Bias
biases.description: Confirmation Bias refers to a tendency for people to favor information that confirms their preconceptions or hypotheses (even if the information isn't true).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Experiments have repeatedly found that people tend to test hypotheses in a one-sided way: by searching for evidence consistent with the hypothesis they have formed at a given time. Confirmation biases are not limited to the collection of evidence. Although two individuals may have the same information, the way they interpret it can be biased. Even if someone has sought and interpreted evidence in a neutral manner, he or she may still remember it selectively to reinforce his/her expectations. So, the Confirmation Bias may operate at three different stages: when gathering evidence, when analyzing the evidence, or when remembering the evidence.

biases.name: Congruence Bias
biases.description: Congruence Bias refers to a tendency for people to test a given hypothesis by trying to directly test it rather than testing alternative hypotheses.
biases.examples: For example, someone might believe that their current diet is the only one they could enjoy and might think that they would be incapable of abstaining from the five soft drinks they have every day. They might directly test and confirm the relationship between their happiness and their diet by repeatedly noticing how happy they feel when they have their soft drinks, but they might be overlooking the fact that they haven't ever tested a key alternative hypothesis: namely, that it might be possible to enjoy other, more nutritious diets.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this bias, one could help people to notice that performing the old behavior without ever having tried alternatives is an invalid way of proving that the old behavior is superior to alternatives.
biases.content:
Congruence Bias refers to a tendency for people to test a given hypothesis by trying to directly test it rather than testing alternative hypotheses.

For example, someone might believe that their current diet is the only one they could enjoy and might think that they would be incapable of abstaining from the five soft drinks they have every day. They might directly test and confirm the relationship between their happiness and their diet by repeatedly noticing how happy they feel when they have their soft drinks, but they might be overlooking the fact that they haven’t ever tested a key alternative hypothesis: namely, that it might be possible to enjoy other, more nutritious diets.

To overcome this bias, one could help people to notice that performing the old behavior without ever having tried alternatives is an invalid way of proving that the old behavior is superior to alternatives.
biases.title: Congruence Bias

biases.name: Pessimism Bias
biases.description: Pessimism bias refers to a tendency for some people, especially those suffering from depression, to overestimate the likelihood of negative occurrences.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this bias, it might help to clearly explain the probability of success and by encouraging the person to consider the evidence that might count against their pessimistic conclusions. One could also help the person to document, celebrate, and remember each successful step towards behavior change (even the small ones - and especially the ones that they did not predict would be possible). If it is not overcome, pessimism bias could negatively affect someone's chances of behavior change at every stage (from the planning through to implementation and maintenance of the behavior). It could also cause a person to form unrealistic underestimates of their abilities, which might distort their reasoning about the best ways of implementing and continuing the behavior or might give them the impression that some behavior change goals or steps could be unattainable for them. (On the other hand, in some cases, pessimism bias might be able to be leveraged for success; for example, if a person is pessimistic enough to plan ahead for setbacks but not so pessimistic that they are discouraged from forming or implementing plans in the first place, then pessimism bias could be helpful in some behavior change contexts.)
biases.content:
Pessimism bias refers to a tendency for some people, especially those suffering from depression, to overestimate the likelihood of negative occurrences.

To overcome this bias, it might help to clearly explain the probability of success and by encouraging the person to consider the evidence that might count against their pessimistic conclusions. One could also help the person to document, celebrate, and remember each successful step towards behavior change (even the small ones - and especially the ones that they did not predict would be possible). If it is not overcome, pessimism bias could negatively affect someone’s chances of behavior change at every stage (from the planning through to implementation and maintenance of the behavior). It could also cause a person to form unrealistic underestimates of their abilities, which might distort their reasoning about the best ways of implementing and continuing the behavior or might give them the impression that some behavior change goals or steps could be unattainable for them. (On the other hand, in some cases, pessimism bias might be able to be leveraged for success; for example, if a person is pessimistic enough to plan ahead for setbacks but not so pessimistic that they are discouraged from forming or implementing plans in the first place, then pessimism bias could be helpful in some behavior change contexts.)
biases.title: Pessimism Bias

biases.name: Subadditivity
biases.description: Subadditivity refers to the tendency to judge the probability of the whole to be less than the sum of the probabilities of the component parts.
biases.experimentalEvidence: For instance, subjects in one experiment judged that the probability of death from cancer in the United States was 18%, the probability from heart attack was 22%, and the probability of death from "other natural causes" was 33%. Other participants judged that the probability of death from a natural cause was 58%. Natural causes are made up precisely of cancer, heart attack, and "other natural causes," however, the sum of the latter three probabilities was 73%, and not 58%. According to Tversky and Koehler (1994) this kind of result is observed consistently.

substeps.title: 6. Chooses to perform each action instead of other available actions
substeps.description:
Even if we remember to perform an action, we're very unlikely to perform that action unless we choose it over the other actions or opportunities that are available to us at the same time. There are various reasons why we may not choose to do an action, even if we've remembered we are supposed to do it:
  1. Temptation—e.g., we may think "It would be more fun and relaxing to watch TV instead"
  2. Unpleasantness—e.g., we may avoid an action because it is unappealing or because we believe it will be unpleasant to carry out
  3. Distraction—e.g., we may start the action but get distracted in the middle by something else
  4. Opportunity Cost—e.g., we may think "It's more important that I do this other thing right now"
  5. Time—e.g., we may think "I don't have enough time to complete this action right now"
  6. Anxiety—e.g., we may feel stressed about the idea of trying to carry out the action, and so avoid attempting it
  7. Confusion—e.g., we may feel uncertainty about how to start the action, and so not start it at all
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...she had decided to watch her favorite TV show instead of going to the therapy appointment.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...he had been continually tempted to eat the non-vegetarian foods already stocked in his house.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't taken a minute to visualize the frightening consequences a new and otherwise exciting research project might cause if that research were to get into the wrong hands.
substeps.question: How can you help the target person or population to prefer and choose the relevant action over other potential actions or opportunities that might be available to them at the same time?

interventions.DESCRIPTION / IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY:: The further out into the future that benefits or costs will be accrued or incurred, the less people care about them. So benefits in one minute are valued more than benefits tomorrow, which are valued more than benefits in one year. One type of discounting is hyperbolic discounting, according to which how much people care about future benefits "fall relatively rapidly for earlier delay periods (as in, from now to one week), but then fall more slowly for longer delay periods (for instance, more than a few days). For example, in a study subjects said they would be indifferent between receiving $15 immediately or $30 after 3 months, $60 after 1 year, or $100 after 3 years. These indifferences reflect annual discount rates that declined from 277% to 139% to 63% as delays got longer. This contrasts with exponential discounting, in which valuation falls by a constant factor per unit delay and the discount rate stays the same." Another effect of hyperbolic discounting is that "many people prefer $100 now to $110 in a day, but very few people prefer $100 in 30 days to $110 in 31 days." In other words: "More generally, the rate at which people discount future rewards declines as the length of the delay increases". When the intrinsic benefit of the behavior change is delayed in time (for example, if a person is trying to lose weight the goal will take at least months to be met), people are more likely to choose to not perform the desired action for the immediate pleasure / reward (eating a bowl of ice cream) because of excessively high rates of discounting, so interventions to address this have to make the delayed reward more desirable or build in immediate rewards (e.g., marking one more day of eating healthy on a tracker).

biases.name: Distinction Bias
biases.description: Distinction Bias refers to a tendency to view two options as more dissimilar to each other when they are simultaneously evaluated than when they are separately evaluated.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Research shows that options presented simultaneously are evaluated differently than the same options presented separately. For example, when televisions are displayed next to each other on the sales floor, the difference in quality between two very similar, high-quality televisions may appear great. A consumer may pay a much higher price for the higher-quality television, even though the difference in quality is imperceptible when the televisions are viewed in isolation.

Even if the differences have little practical relevance, the differences between the two options may appear more pronounced while the person is evaluating them together than if the person were to evaluate the desirability of the two options separately.

To leverage this bias, one could bring the old behavior and the new behavior into contrast, exploring the pros and cons of each. Otherwise, people may not think of the behaviors as competing with each other (and thus may not compare them to each other), or they may think that the behaviors are similar enough that choosing one over the other doesn't matter very much.

To overcome this bias, remind people that merely beginning a new, positive behavior may be more important than perfecting the actual implementation details. For example, going to the gym at all is much more important than choosing the right gym with 100% certainty, so flipping a coin to make the decision might enable the person to make a quick choice and begin their new exercise routine without getting hung up on comparing gyms.

biases.description: Loss Aversion refers to people's tendency to prefer avoiding losses to acquiring gains.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Recent studies have questioned the existence of loss aversion. One found that loss aversion does not exist in small payoff magnitudes. Another found that loss aversion is more likely to affect a person in competitive situations. [next sentences are taken from the old version of the description column:] Some studies suggest that losses are twice as powerful, psychologically, as gains. Whether a transaction is framed as a loss or a gain is very important: would you rather get a $5 discount (win), or avoid a $5 surcharge (loss)? The same change in price framed differently has a significant effect on consumer behavior. In other words, losses have a more profound effect on us than does a gain of the same value. This is related to the Endowment Effect, and was once thought to be an consequence of it.

biases.name: Two Wrongs Make a Right Fallacy
biases.description: The "Two Wrongs Make a Right" Fallacy is the fallacious assumption that one moral wrongdoing can be justified by another wrongdoing.
biases.examples: An example of this reasoning might arise when someone tries to justify treating someone inhumanely by referring to how the victim did things to "deserve" it. This kind of reasoning can also be considered to be a form of moral disengagement. (Moral disengagement is a form of reasoning whereby people escape feelings of culpability by reconceptualizing their immoral actions as being virtuous or otherwise justified.)
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, it might help to ask people to consider how they'd feel if someone else (or their past or future selves) committed the same two wrongdoings. For example, imagine that a person failed to go to the gym one day and then thought, "Well, I failed today, so I might as well have some cake, too!" Ask the person if they would condone these behaviors if someone else (or a past or future version of themself) performed them.
biases.content:
The “Two Wrongs Make a Right” Fallacy is the fallacious assumption that one moral wrongdoing can be justified by another wrongdoing.

An example of this reasoning might arise when someone tries to justify treating someone inhumanely by referring to how the victim did things to “deserve” it. This kind of reasoning can also be considered to be a form of moral disengagement. (Moral disengagement is a form of reasoning whereby people escape feelings of culpability by reconceptualizing their immoral actions as being virtuous or otherwise justified.)

To overcome this fallacy, it might help to ask people to consider how they’d feel if someone else (or their past or future selves) committed the same two wrongdoings. For example, imagine that a person failed to go to the gym one day and then thought, “Well, I failed today, so I might as well have some cake, too!” Ask the person if they would condone these behaviors if someone else (or a past or future version of themself) performed them.

biases.name: Unit Bias
biases.description: Unit Bias refers to a preference for finishing a given unit of a task or an item.
biases.examples: For example, someone may prefer to finish a whole packet (unit) of chips once they have opened them. Another example may arise if someone bought a six-pack of beer to share with a friend, for instance. The pair may drink two beers each and may be satisfied. They may then decide that they would prefer to finish the whole pack (in which case the unit bias would encourage them to drink more than they otherwise would).
biases.benevolentHelper: To leverage this bias, it might help to change the unit size (e.g., reduce the portion size for food, break the task into smaller subtasks, etc.). It might also help to ask people to set goals and limits before starting and to ask them to adhere to those goals and limits (while working, eating, etc.).

biases.name: Dunning–Kruger Effect
biases.description: The Dunning-Kruger Effect refers to a phenomenon in which people who are less adept at a particular skill appear to overestimate their abilities (suffering from illusory superiority), while those who are more highly skilled appear to underestimate their abilities (suffering from illusory inferiority).
biases.experimentalEvidence:
Dunning and Kruger concluded, "across four studies, the authors found that participants scoring in the bottom quartile on tests of humor, grammar, and logic grossly overestimated their test performance and ability. Although test scores put them in the 12th percentile, they estimated themselves to be in the 62nd." Meanwhile, people with true ability tended to underestimate their relative competence. Roughly, participants who found tasks to be relatively easy erroneously assumed, to some extent, that the tasks must also be easy for others.

Studies on the Dunning–Kruger Effect tend to focus on American test subjects. Similar studies on European subjects show marked muting of the effect; studies on some East Asian subjects suggest that something like the opposite of the Dunning–Kruger effect operates on self-assessment and motivation to improve. As Kruger and Dunning noted, "the miscalibration of the incompetent stems from an error about the self, whereas the miscalibration of the highly competent stems from an error about others."
