biases.content:
The Dunning-Kruger Effect refers to a phenomenon in which people who are less adept at a particular skill appear to overestimate their abilities (suffering from illusory superiority), while those who are more highly skilled appear to underestimate their abilities (suffering from illusory inferiority).

For example, “That NFL coach is an idiot! I only played football for two years in high school, but I’d do a way better job than him at coaching that team!”

To overcome this fallacy, it might help to point out that, in general, people with less knowledge of an area are less equipped to assess their own skill level in that area and less equipped to understand the relative difficulty of that behavior. Also, giving people an objective test of skill or knowledge in the relevant area may show them where they lie relative to others and thus help to calibrate their judgment about their own abilities.

biases.name: Zeigarnik Effect in Memory
biases.description: The Zeigarnik Effect refers to a tendency for people to remember uncompleted or interrupted tasks better than completed tasks. It is named after Bluma Zeigarnik, who studied this effect in her dissertation.
biases.experimentalEvidence: Soviet psychologist Bluma Zeigarnik first studied the phenomenon after her professor, Gestalt psychologist Kurt Lewin, noticed that a waiter had better recollections of still unpaid orders. In Gestalt psychology, the Zeigarnik effect has been used to demonstrate the general presence of Gestalt phenomena: not just appearing as perceptual effects, but also present in cognition. The Zeigarnik effect suggests that students who "suspend" their study, during which they do unrelated activities (such as studying unrelated subjects or playing games), will remember material better than students who complete study sessions without a break (Zeigarnik, 1927; McKinney 1935).

substeps.title: 8. Has needed resources and permission to perform each action
substeps.description:
We're very unlikely to perform a specific action unless we have the resources we need to perform that action effectively.

There are a number of different things we may fail to have that can prevent us from performing an action:

  • Money - e.g., there may be a cost associated with the action, such as a gym membership fee
  • Supplies - e.g., we may need supplies or equipment to perform the action, such as dumbbells for exercise
  • Technology - e.g., we might not be able to perform the action without sufficiently up-to-date technology, such as a smart phone that's modern enough to run the latest apps
  • Assistance - e.g., if we can't carry an action out alone, we may require assistance; for instance, a person who has severely impaired vision may need assistance in navigating environments that are made for sighted people
  • Transportation - e.g., if we can't get to the right location, we may not be able to perform the required action
  • Permission - e.g., if we can't get the necessary permission to perform an action, such as parental permission for a child or a boss's permission for employees, we may not be able to perform the action
  • Legal Authorization - e.g., if an action goes against rules, laws, or regulations, we are unlikely to be able to carry it out even if it doesn't harm anyone and is beneficial
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have begun to visit a therapist for her anxiety if...she hadn't been able to use public transportation that could drop her off near her therapist's office.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have become vegetarian if...he hadn't bought vegetarian ingredients to replace the non-vegetarian ones he already had in his home.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have reduced the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't included a line item in her grant budget for doing risk assessments on her projects.

biases.name: Fundamental Attribution Error
biases.description: Fundamental Attribution Error refers to a tendency for people to explain others' behaviors in a way that overemphasizes their personal characteristics and underemphasizes environmental or situational factors. See also: Actor-Observer Asymmetry
biases.experimentalEvidence:
Jones and Harris hypothesized, based on the correspondent inference theory, that people would attribute apparently freely chosen behaviors to disposition and apparently chance-directed behaviors to situation. The hypothesis was confounded by the Fundamental Attribution Error.

Subjects in an experiment read essays for and against Fidel Castro. Then they were asked to rate the pro-Castro attitudes of the writers. When the subjects believed that the writers freely chose positions for or against Castro, they would normally rate the people who liked Castro as having a more positive attitude towards Castro. However, contradicting Jones and Harris' initial hypothesis, when the subjects were told that the writers' positions were determined by a coin toss, they still rated writers who spoke in favor of Castro as having, on average, a more positive attitude towards Castro than those who spoke against him. In other words, the subjects were unable to properly see the influence of the situational constraints placed upon the writers; they could not refrain from attributing sincere belief to the writers. The experimental group provided more internal attributions towards the writer.

biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this effect, one could point it out and provide suggestions for alternative ways of thinking about the situation in question, with particular attention paid to the environmental factors. Otherwise, the error might lead to unrealistic expectations regarding the relative importance of personal characteristics in achieving the behavior change and its associated outcomes. (This is because, when people observe others experiencing the positive effects of a behavior, they may attribute people's success to personal characteristics rather than to the environmental and social facilitators of the behavior and its outcomes.) Therefore, people may not consider other important barriers and enablers to their behavior change efforts, such as those in their physical and social environment. (The upsides to this might include a greater focus on developing specific personal characteristics and knowledge, which could nevertheless help them in other ways. Thus, the relative (dis)advantages associated with this effect could vary according to which condition for change is most important to meet to facilitate the behavior in question.)

biases.name: Illusion of Transparency
biases.description: The Illusion of Transparency refers to a tendency to overestimate how easily one's mental state can be discerned by others (i.e., how transparent it is). Relatedly, an Observer's Illusion of Transparency refers to a tendency for people to overestimate the transparency of the mental states of those they observe (causing them to overestimate the degree to which they can discern others' mental states).
biases.experimentalEvidence: [taken from original description column] Initial anxiety in a public speaking situation can cause stress that, because of the Illusion of Transparency, the speaker may feel is evident to the listeners. This mistaken perception can cause the speaker to compensate, which he or she then feels is even more obvious to the crowd, and the stress increases in a feedback loop. Awareness of the limits of others' perceptions of one's mental state can help break the cycle and reduce speech anxiety.

biases.name: No True Scotsman Fallacy
biases.description: The No True Scotsman Fallacy refers to the fallacious assumption that one can still defend a universal claim even when faced with a counterexample of it, as long as one simply redefines the universal claim as specifically excluding that counterexample.
biases.examples: For example, someone might believe that all people who learn a particular skill must do so through a specific school or training program in order to be considered "truly" skilled at the behavior in question. If they are given counterexamples of people who learned the skill through other mechanisms, they may then claim that the people who learned the skill via those alternative mechanisms are not "truly" skilled.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy when it is counterproductively influencing behavior, it might help to encourage the person to consider reevaluating the situation in light of new information. Over the longer-term, it might help to encourage the person to develop probabilistic and nuanced thinking. In this way, they might become less inclined to categorize things as being "always" a certain way.
biases.content:
The No True Scotsman Fallacy refers to the fallacious assumption that one can still defend a universal claim even when faced with a counterexample of it, as long as one simply redefines the universal claim as specifically excluding that counterexample.

For example, someone might believe that all people who learn a particular skill must do so through a specific school or training program in order to be considered “truly” skilled at the behavior in question. If they are given counterexamples of people who learned the skill through other mechanisms, they may then claim that the people who learned the skill via those alternative mechanisms are not “truly” skilled.

To overcome this fallacy when it is counterproductively influencing behavior, it might help to encourage the person to consider reevaluating the situation in light of new information. Over the longer-term, it might help to encourage the person to develop probabilistic and nuanced thinking. In this way, they might become less inclined to categorize things as being “always” a certain way.

biases.name: Planning Fallacy
biases.description: The Planning Fallacy is a tendency for people and organizations to underestimate how long they will need to complete a task. This can apply even when they have past experience of similar tasks taking longer than expected. The bias only appears to affect predictions about one's own tasks; when uninvolved observers predict task completion times, they appear to show a pessimistic bias, overestimating the time taken.
biases.experimentalEvidence: In 2003, Lovallo and Kahneman proposed an expanded definition as the tendency to underestimate the time, costs, and risks of future actions and at the same time overestimate the benefits of the same actions. In a 1994 study, 37 psychology students were asked to estimate how long it would take to finish their senior theses. The average estimate was 33.9 days. They also estimated how long it would take "if everything went as well as it possibly could" (averaging 27.4 days) and "if everything went as poorly as it possibly could" (averaging 48.6 days). The average actual completion time was 55.5 days, with only about 30% of the students completing their thesis in the amount of time they predicted.

biases.name: Self-Serving Bias
biases.description: Self-Serving Bias refers to a cognitive bias whereby people tend to attribute their successes to internal or personal factors while attributing their failures to situational factors beyond their control.
biases.experimentalEvidence: [taken from description column, these next sentences represent more explanations than descriptions of the bias.] The Self-serving Bias can be seen in the common human tendency to take credit for success but to deny responsibility for failure. There are several possible causes of this bias. People are motivated to protect their self-esteem; they may be attempting to protect their reputation by advertising successes and shifting blame for failures publicly, regardless of their true understanding of the situation. Additionally, success may be more readily available to memory than failure.

biases.content:
Self-Serving Bias refers to a cognitive bias whereby people tend to attribute their successes to internal or personal factors while attributing their failures to situational factors beyond their control.

For example, suppose someone aims to engage in five 30-minute sessions of aerobic exercise per week. If they fail to do this in a given week, they may attribute their failure to external factors such as work and family commitments, weather conditions, and so on. They may also overlook the contributions of internal factors, such as time management, motivation levels, and procrastination.

To overcome this bias when it is suspected to be counterproductively influencing someone’s behavior, it may help to point out the other factors that can contribute to specific outcomes (beyond the factors that the person is assuming to be involved). When someone has failed at something, they may benefit from acknowledging and learning from the ways in which their personal characteristics could have contributed to that failure. And when someone has succeeded at something, it might help their future chances of success if they recognize the situational factors that contributed to their success (e.g., so that they can try to recreate these in the future). (There are some similarities between this bias and the Illusion of Control. Self-serving bias, however, differs in how people respond to failure, so it presents different obstacles to behavioral change compared to the Illusion of Control.)

substeps.title: 9. Embodies skills and traits needed to perform each action
substeps.description:
We're very unlikely to perform a specific action unless we have the physical capacities, mental capabilities, and skills needed to perform that action. For instance, even if someone knows how to use a weight machine (as a part of their fitness plan), they may be physically incapable of using the machine if they have a shoulder injury. We may fail to embody all the traits needed to carry out an action for various reasons:
  1. Physical Characteristics—e.g., we may not have sufficient strength or balance to carry out an action
  2. Injuries—e.g., we may have a hand injury that prevents us from carrying out the action safely
  3. Physical Disabilities or Handicaps—e.g., if we are blind, we are not going to be able to carry out actions that require sight
  4. Mental Characteristics—e.g., if we have severe dyslexia, we may find it difficult to carry out actions that involve reading complex material
  5. Skills—e.g., if an action involves a difficult series of steps, we may require training to build the skills necessary to carry out the action

substeps.title: 10. Maintains attributes required to perform future needed actions
substeps.description: We're very unlikely to perform future required actions if, due to the experience of taking earlier actions or due to the passage of time, the conditions mentioned above (Desires, Intends, Remembers, Believes, etc.) fall below adequate levels. For example, after taking the first action in a sequence of actions that compose a new behavior, a person may become discouraged if the action doesn't go well. So, even if the Believes condition was previously met for that action, it may no longer be met after the person has attempted the action once. Or a person may initially meet the Desires condition for a new behavior but might cease to meet that condition as time passes if they forget why they cared about adopting the behavior in the first place.
substeps.example1: Abby wouldn't have continued visiting her therapist for her anxiety if...she hadn't made a firm commitment to the therapist to come to their office every Monday at 6pm.
substeps.example2: Ben wouldn't have continued living a vegetarian lifestyle if...he hadn't pre-planned an exciting trip as a reward for sticking to the diet for 3 months.
substeps.example3: Clay wouldn't have continued reducing the societal risk associated with her research if...she hadn't made a public commitment during a talk she gave to consider societal risk in all of her future projects.

interventions.DESCRIPTION / IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY::
Apply the "mental contrasting" technique, which involves focusing on positive aspects of a goal, and the barriers standing in the way of achieving that goal:

1a) Write down or think about several positive aspects associated with completing your goal. For example, if you’re trying to lose weight, those positive aspects could be: looking good, living longer, spending less on healthcare, feeling more lively, being able to stay active, getting your spouse to stop nagging you, etc…
1b) Hone in the most positive aspects. This could be one especially large benefit or a few smaller ones. Then take a few moments to visualize those benefits. The longer and the more detail, the better.
2a) Write down or think about several obstacles in the way of you completing your goal. For example, if you’re trying to lose weight, those obstacles could be: being tempted by snacks, purchasing unhealthy food while shopping, eating too much at dinner, emotional binging, lack of motivation to exercise, etc…
2b) Home in the largest obstacles. This could be one especially large obstacle or a few smaller ones. Then take a few moments to visualize those obstacles. The longer and the more detail, the better.

biases.name: Change Bias in Memory
biases.description: Change Bias in Memory refers to a phenomenon wherein someone who engaged in effortful behavior change later overestimates how challenging their past performance or behavior was. See also: Choice-Supportive Bias.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this phenomenon, encourage people to keep a diary documenting their efforts over time so that they can return to previous entries to remind themselves of how effortful their past performance actually was.
sourceDescriptions: Psychology and Cognitive Neuroscience". American Psychologist 54 (3): 182-203. doi:10.1037/0003-066X.54.3.182. PMID 10199218
biases.content:
Change Bias in Memory refers to a phenomenon wherein someone who engaged in effortful behavior change later overestimates how challenging their past performance or behavior was. See also: Choice-Supportive Bias.

To overcome this phenomenon, encourage people to keep a diary documenting their efforts over time so that they can return to previous entries to remind themselves of how effortful their past performance actually was.
biases.title: Change Bias in Memory

biases.name: Choice-Supportive Bias
biases.description: Choice-Supportive Bias refers to a cognitive bias whereby someone who has made a choice between different options later remembers the option that they chose as having more positive attributes than it did at the time (while they remember options they did not choose as having more negative attributes than they'd had at the time).
biases.experimentalEvidence: Research indicates that the process of making and remembering choices yields memories that tend to be distorted in predictable ways. For example, one predictable way that memories of choices are distorted is that positive aspects tend to be remembered as part of the chosen option, regardless of whether they originally part of that option, and negative aspects tend to be remembered as part of rejected options. This may affect a person's regret or approval of past decisions, and may also influence future decision-making.

Currently, the cell's content is taken.com/forgetting/: This would need rewording. Depending on the level of depth we want to go into when explaining the evidence supporting the existence of particular biases, I would feel the need to go and find the actual studies before describing and citing them. :S Currently, though, this comes from https://scienceswitch.com/choice-supportive-bias/

biases.examples: For example, someone who chose to undertake an expensive and time-consuming course in order to gain a particular skill may retrospectively remember many positive aspects of the course they chose (even if these did not enter into their decision at the time), and may remember the alternative options as being worse than they were (e.g., they may overestimate how unpleasant or difficult it would have been to learn the skill another way, to gain more work experience while still learning the skill, and so on).
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this bias, one could help people to notice the ways in which they seek to justify their old behavior. People may often overweight the benefits of the old behavior as a way of justifying that behavior, so helping them to notice that they're doing this may help them to be more mindful about giving up the old behavior and adopting the new behavior.
biases.anthonysNotes: "people who say "I have no regrets" about my life... why are regrets taboo? can you make mistakes but not regret them?
biases.content:
Choice-Supportive Bias refers to a cognitive bias whereby someone who has made a choice between different options later remembers the option that they chose as having more positive attributes than it did at the time (while they remember options they did not choose as having more negative attributes than they’d had at the time).

For example, someone who chose to undertake an expensive and time-consuming course in order to gain a particular skill may retrospectively remember many positive aspects of the course they chose (even if these did not enter into their decision at the time), and may remember the alternative options as being worse than they were (e.g., they may overestimate how unpleasant or difficult it would have been to learn the skill another way, to gain more work experience while still learning the skill, and so on).

To overcome this bias, one could help people to notice the ways in which they seek to justify their old behavior. People may often overweight the benefits of the old behavior as a way of justifying that behavior, so helping them to notice that they’re doing this may help them to be more mindful about giving up the old behavior and adopting the new behavior.
biases.title: Choice-Supportive Bias

biases.name: Disregard of Regression Toward the Mean
biases.description: Disregard of Regression Toward the Mean refers to any case of reasoning that fails to take into account the tendency for random events to exhibit regression toward the mean. "Regression toward the mean" refers to the observation that when sampling a random variable, an extreme (or very unlikely) outcome will, on average, be followed by less extreme outcomes. (Note that the Gambler's Fallacy does *not* represent a rational solution to this problem because Gambler's Fallacy involves the inaccurate belief that a future event "compensates" for a past event, and that is not what is happening in regression toward the mean.)
biases.examples: For example, someone may say, "When his pain got worse, he went to a doctor, after which the pain subsided somewhat. Therefore, he benefited from the doctor's treatment." This person seems to to be assuming that the pain would have continued without the doctor's treatment. In many cases, though, patients tend to visit a doctor at the worst point of their illness, after which time they would get better anyway, even without a doctor's intervention.
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome or avoid this phenomenon, it might help to point this out when it occurs and to show it is a fallacy. Provide statistics showing that a person's particular experiences are rare and thus likely to be followed by more common experiences.
biases.ideasForTesting: Bob, John, and Phil play 24 games of Monopoly against one another. Bob wins 14 of these games, while Jon wins 6 and Phil wins 4. If they play another 24 games of Monopoly against one another, which of the three of them is the most likely to win fewer games than they won over the course of the previous 24 games? A. Bob B. John C. Phil D. They are all equally likely E. There is not enough information to make a prediction.
biases.evenMoreNotes: Bob, John, Phil, Tim, and Dave play 40 games of Monopoly against one another. Bob wins 16 of these games, while John wins 9, Phil wins 7, and Tim and Dave each win 4. If they play another 40 games of Monopoly against one another, who is more likely to win fewer games than they won over the course of the previous 40, Bob or Phil?
biases.content:
Disregard of Regression Toward the Mean refers to any case of reasoning that fails to take into account the tendency for random events to exhibit regression toward the mean. “Regression toward the mean” refers to the observation that when sampling a random variable, an extreme (or very unlikely) outcome will, on average, be followed by less extreme outcomes. (Note that the Gambler’s Fallacy does not represent a rational solution to this problem because Gambler’s Fallacy involves the inaccurate belief that a future event “compensates” for a past event, and that is not what is happening in regression toward the mean.)

For example, someone may say, “When his pain got worse, he went to a doctor, after which the pain subsided somewhat. Therefore, he benefited from the doctor’s treatment.” This person seems to to be assuming that the pain would have continued without the doctor’s treatment. In many cases, though, patients tend to visit a doctor at the worst point of their illness, after which time they would get better anyway, even without a doctor’s intervention.

To overcome or avoid this phenomenon, it might help to point this out when it occurs and to show it is a fallacy. Provide statistics showing that a person’s particular experiences are rare and thus likely to be followed by more common experiences.
biases.title: Disregard of Regression Toward the Mean

biases.content:
Fading Affect Bias in Memory refers to a tendency for the emotions associated with unpleasant memories to fade more quickly than the emotions associated with pleasant memories.

For example, someone who quit binge drinking several months ago may forget their hangovers, vomiting episodes, and the time that they were so drunk that they locked themselves out of their apartment, but they may look back wistfully on the fun they remember having when they used to drink more than they currently do.

To overcome this bias, encourage people to keep a diary documenting their affective experiences over time. They can return to previous entries to remind themselves of how emotionally varied (as opposed to uniformly positive) their past experiences actually were. This may be particularly important to ensure the Maintains condition continues to be met (otherwise, the person may be at risk of becoming demotivated if they believe that things were better before they changed their behavior in this way).

biases.name: Fallacy of Gray
biases.description: The Fallacy of Gray is a belief that because nothing is certain, everything is equally uncertain. (That is, this fallacy overlooks the fact that it is possible to quantify and to compare different levels of uncertainty.) Everything may be shades of gray, but there are shades of gray so light as to be very nearly white, and shades of gray so dark as to be very nearly black. Or even if not, we can still compare shades, and say "it is darker" or "it is lighter". This fallacy is invoked by those who wish to attack a well performing system (e.g., science), by saying that it is still imperfect. This then excuses the imperfections of the invoker's chosen system.
biases.examples:
For example: "Scientists can't tell us with 100% certainty what happened at the beginning of the universe, so my theory about what happened is just as good as yours."

As another example, someone might be trying to convince their chronically sleep-deprived friend to prioritize getting enough sleep. Upon being presented with a large body of evidence showing the positive health impacts of getting adequate amounts of sleep, the friend may decide not to put any weight on that evidence because "everything in science is uncertain."
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome this fallacy, encourage probabilistic thinking. Say things like: "Just because outcomes aren't certain doesn't mean that we can't know *anything* about how likely they are. You're *much* more likely to make money by working at a steady job than by gambling all day, so you should work on giving up your gambling habit and apply for a job."

(That is, this fallacy overlooks the fact that it is possible to quantify and to compare different levels of uncertainty.) Everything may be shades of gray, but there are shades of gray so light as to be very nearly white, and shades of gray so dark as to be very nearly black. Or even if not, we can still compare shades, and say “it is darker” or “it is lighter”. This fallacy is invoked by those who wish to attack a well performing system (e.g., science), by saying that it is still imperfect. This then excuses the imperfections of the invoker’s chosen system.

For example: “Scientists can’t tell us with 100% certainty what happened at the beginning of the universe, so my theory about what happened is just as good as yours.”

As another example, someone might be trying to convince their chronically sleep-deprived friend to prioritize getting enough sleep. Upon being presented with a large body of evidence showing the positive health impacts of getting adequate amounts of sleep, the friend may decide not to put any weight on that evidence because “everything in science is uncertain.”

To overcome this fallacy, encourage probabilistic thinking. Say things like: “Just because outcomes aren’t certain doesn’t mean that we can’t know anything about how likely they are. You’re much more likely to make money by working at a steady job than by gambling all day, so you should work on giving up your gambling habit and apply for a job.”

biases.name: Historian's Fallacy
biases.description: Historian's Fallacy refers to the fallacious assumption that historical decision-makers had the same information available to them and viewed events from the same perspective as the people who later analyze their decisions.
biases.manualKeywords: history, decision, information, perspective, analyze, later, future, past
biases.benevolentHelper: To overcome or avoid this fallacy, it might help to notice when it occurs and to plan ways to avoid its recurrence. For example, someone might notice this fallacy (or one very similar to it) coming into play when reviewing their behavior change diary (or a similar method of keeping track of their behavior change goals and their progress towards them). When reviewing their past plans, they might conclude that their past self should have known how the behavioral change plans would work out. The person could notice that they might be falling prey to this fallacy and question their assumptions about the situation. They could also avoid this in the future by additionally recording the _reasons_ that they set specific goals (and made specific plans to meet them). That way, when they later look back on their plans, they might more easily identify the gaps in their knowledge that caused them to form plans in the way that they did. This might lead to less self-criticism, as well as a richer source of information from which they can learn, in cases where they have had a behavioral lapse.

biases.name: Hyperbolic Discounting
biases.description: Hyperbolic Discounting refers to the tendency for people to discount the value of rewards that occur later in time, with valuations falling rapidly with earlier delays (e.g., getting a reward now versus in three days) and much less rapidly with later delays (e.g., getting a reward in a year versus a year and three days from now).
biases.experimentalEvidence: The standard experiment used to reveal a test subject's hyperbolic discounting curve is to compare short-term preferences with long-term preferences. For instance: "Would you prefer a dollar today or three dollars tomorrow?" or "Would you prefer a dollar in one year or three dollars in one year and one day?" For certain ranges of offerings, a significant fraction of subjects will take the lesser amount today, but will gladly wait one extra day in a year in order to receive the higher amount instead.

biases.name: Prosecutor's Fallacy
biases.description: The Prosecutor's Fallacy refers to the fallacious assumption that the accuracy of an accusation against someone has no relationship with the specific context in which the accusation was made. It arose and is usually used in a legal context; it stems from a [statistical misunderstanding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecutor%27s_fallacy#Mathematical_analysis), and it affects how people weigh evidence against an accused person.
biases.examples: Although this fallacy can refer to a legal phenomenon, the same fallacy could also affect statistical reasoning in other areas. For example, suppose that someone hypothesizes that they will fail at the behavior they are trying to start. If that person then notices some evidence that they are indeed struggling with the behavior, they might conclude that they will be one of the people who permanently fail at this particular goal. In doing so, they might fail to realize that the same evidence would also be present for people who go on to succeed with the behavior change.

One can also read about how Bayes' Theorem can be [useful](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosecutor%27s_fallacy#Mathematical_analysis) for trying to avoid the Prosecutor's Fallacy.
biases.content:
The Prosecutor’s Fallacy refers to the fallacious assumption that the accuracy of an accusation against someone has no relationship with the specific context in which the accusation was made. It arose and is usually used in a legal context; it stems from a statistical misunderstanding, and it affects how people weigh evidence against an accused person.

Although this fallacy can refer to a legal phenomenon, the same fallacy could also affect statistical reasoning in other areas. For example, suppose that someone hypothesizes that they will fail at the behavior they are trying to start. If that person then notices some evidence that they are indeed struggling with the behavior, they might conclude that they will be one of the people who permanently fail at this particular goal. In doing so, they might fail to realize that the same evidence would also be present for people who go on to succeed with the behavior change.

To overcome this fallacy, it may help to draw a diagram or to sit down and estimate the actual probabilities or odds of the outcomes about which one is trying to think. People who seem to be affected by the Prosecutor’s Fallacy might also benefit from an understanding of Bayes’ Theorem](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZGCoVF3YvM) and how to use it in everyday reasoning. One can also read about how Bayes’ Theorem can be useful for trying to avoid the Prosecutor’s Fallacy.

This might mean that they don’t invest their time/effort as often as they should.)
